text: When they first open the restaurant. The quality was excellent the quality of the food has dropped down 75%. The pasta was dry with not much Pasta sauce. the waiter was very rude and annoying. My friends were not as pleased as I highly had recommended this place. We spent over $300. We will never return or recommend this place. We will find another Italian Restaurant. I imagine those that goes the first time when I go back
Ek, mediocre food and rude service. I recommend spending your money some where you will feel appreciated.
Don't really like to write bad reviews, but I kind of had to. Food was ok, but they were pretty rude to us. Hope they can make some changes and improve their service
Food was good. My wife and I loved the seating in the back room. I was never in Italy, but it wasn't hard to imagine we were there.

Hate to have to lower my rating for this restaurant I once loved. Came here last night to be extremely disappointed by the service. It was almost impossible to get any attention from the waiters, and they seemed annoyed and confused when we wanted to order our food after sitting unattended for 20 minutes. Once we finished our appetizers, a waiter gave us dessert menus before we even received our entrees. We also watched as one server kept putting his fingers in his ear - at that point we decided to leave before our entrees arrived. Very upset to see this place be brought down by bad service.

I have been here a few times now, I especially love the atmosphere and decorations. You feel like you are in Italy! The food is good and they always have interesting and different specials. We had the calamari to start and I loved that it was sautéed and now fried! The bread that comes with the meal is very good and includes focaccia. For a meal I had seafood risotto and it was tasty. It's not the best Italian food I've ever had but a solid place to go on Arthur Ave with a great vibe!

Very unimpressed by this place. We joined the wait list through yelp and still had to wait 20 minutes for a table because they didn't really acknowledge that. The service is super fast because they want to get you out real quick. The food was okay. I really wanted to try the butternut squash pizza with truffle oil and mushrooms because it sounded really good but it was not. My boyfriend got the pancetta pizza and it was oily and not that great. As far as the wine, they don't really have a large selection. Basically, keep walking and find a better place in the area.

Dont come here if you want to have quality time. I came here around 6pm on Friday. Rushed through entire meal. They tried to take my place twice when Im not done eating. Third time - im like take it. I asked chocolate mousse to be cut in half, waiter snatches knief from next empty table and cuts in half with fork, smooshing half of mousse. NO JOKE. After bill is paid, they came to take unsigned receipt and brought it back. Then they do get out stare. Im like - they must be super busy and have absolutely no empty table. Entire front section is empty. I was out by 7:02pm. Food wasnt bad, but so as all the other italian restaurant in this area. If you want civilized and quality time, DO NOT COME HERE.

The pizza is definitely very top quality--a friend and I came here for lunch over the weekend, and that was a good time to go (was able to get a seat w/o a reservation). The margherita pizza was extremely good. We also ordered some mussels (big and delicious!) and stuffed pepper with other roasted veggies. The service was--okay. I can see what some of the other Yelpers are saying. The staff/management were a bit difficult to track down (re: asking about food restrictions, for example)--but once they were available, all was okay. I can imagine during a particularly busy time, it may even a little more hectic. But the pizza alone is worth the trip out to Arthur Ave to check out--it was truly delicious. And the environment has an open feel to it--really enjoyed that, as well.

The nagatives first: I had reserved a table through Yelp and we still had to wait 20 minutes for our table. Not sure it actually did anything for us. The food took an hour to prepare and they didnt refill our bread basket (maybe they dont do that there?) Also, the drinks were only ok. I ordered the Americano Negroni off the dinner menu (it was disgusting, tasted like Pine-sol. Everyone else at my table tasted it and agreed it was gross) so I asked to return the drink and get something else. The server, while overall very nice, was taken aback by my request and made me feel bad for sending the drink back which I did not like. He brought me the bar menu which ended up not even having my original drink on it (Americano Negroni), so it made me wonder if maybe they took it off the bar menu because it was gross... Everyone else liked their drinks but agreed that they were only OK, not spectacular. The next drink I ordered barely had any alcohol in it. So.... definitely dont come here for the mix drinks.Now for the positives: the food was fantastic! The bread and olive oil they serve while you're waiting is phenomenal. The focaccia was my favorite, but dipping the other in the olive oil sprinkled with some salt and pepper, ohhhhh man so good. 3 of us ordered pizza, I ordered the Margherita pizza. It was so delicious and the servings are pretty big. I took half of it home because I couldn't finish it all (although my dad ate his whole pizza so they're not SO big). One of the girls ordered pasta and another ordered the pear salad (as an entree, 2 others got it as appetizers) Everyone loved their food. Very flavorful, fresh, and delicious. Also the ambiance of the place is very nice and quaint (even though we all had to yell to hear each other talk lol). Summary: food was delicious, drinks were only ok, service was decent but not great. I would definitely go back but only for the food and maybe a bit earlier when it's less crowded.
The food was outstanding.  We started with a Margherita Pizza. The crust was perfect!  The Ragu was very flavorful.  The chicken dish was great.  The staff is very friendly.
Pizza's pretty good (nothing special), the people not so much. Also good luck if you wanna get a coke in this neighborhood.

I'm very torn about this review. Food was delicious. Ambiance was great. Service was weird. Our waiter was great reading off the specials then once we ordered we never saw him again. Other people dropped off our food. There was at least a 10 minute wait between our appetizers and entrees. We also never got our brussels sprouts, but the people delivering our food said they couldn't give it to us until they asked our waiter. We were never asked how the food was. I had a glass of wine at the beginning of the meal, was never offered another glass and our water was only refilled when we waved someone over. We had to flag down people who walked by to get our bill and to go containers--none which were our waiter. The waiter did drop off our bill, but wouldn't make eye contact with us when doing so. I should note our waiter was in the dining room the whole time, mostly talking to the hostess, and probably saw we were annoyed. With all the good options on Arthur Ave, I will likely try something else next time.

Very good reliable Italian restaurant in Arthur Ave. Food and service was good. We would eat here again if we were in the bronx again. Seafood salad, pizza, cavetelli pasta and seafood risotto were very good but just short of excellent. Their Chianti was excellent. Greeting and service were attentive and courteous.

Went to Zero Otto Nove in the Bronx and it was sooooo much better than the one in Flatiron. We got the margarita pizza, the sauce was flavorful and it was fresher. Also tried one of the pasta specials for the first time. It comes out wrapped in foil and they unveil if for you right in front of you. I've never experienced this before, the pasta was perfectly evenly cooked. I'm already thinking about how we can plan our next trip!

We loved this place. It was friendly, delicious and quick. The menu and specials gave a wide range of choices from favorites to southern Italian specific family favorites. We'll be back, with friends next time.

I am very sad to update my review and lower it by so much. Honestly a major factor this time, as was an issue noted in my last review was the service which was once again very poor. It seemed like the staff were upset to get us additional drink refills or some extra cheese. The entrées also left a lot to be desired. The beef short ribs were somehow a bit tough and the cavatelli were bland. The chicken dish I had which is pictured was pretty good but needed some extra cheese and for sure had way to much tomato on top. The pasta dish pictured was also good but just nothing great.After trying this places a few times i have come to a clear conclusion. The pizza is absolutely phenomenal. We had a margarita today was tremendous even while the entrées were just average. I highly suggest making this a go to lunch spot just for pizzas, but if you are looking for a great meal, there are better options in the area

I actually frequented this place for several years now so I'm shocked I've never written a review before.  The food is spot on, especially the eggplant parmasean. This place sets the standard for me, and not too many have hit above it. The espresso martini is the best I've had. Staff is always friendly. They've upgraded the already nice decor and expanded over the years. This is the place to dine folks. Trust me...come here!!!

Amazing Italian restaurant right in the heart of the Bronx, just down the street from the Botanical Gardens! My first time in the Bronx and wasn't disappointed at all, this place rivals any top Italian place that I've been to, and has the ambiance to go with it!Between the four of us we got a sausage/cheese pizza, ratatore pasta, and calamari & mussels. All were amazingly good and even though I had my doubts about whether this would fill us up, was totally stuffed the rest of the day. Highly recommend coming to check this place out, drinks are somewhat generic but come for the food!!

We were on our way to the botanical gardens and wanted to grab lunch before our visit. Since we went on a Saturday during the holiday season, I wasn't surprised there was a bit of a wait. The 30-45 minutes was actually the perfect amount of time to explore the other shops and bakeries in the Little Italy of the Bronx. Even though they usually close at 2:30, they stayed open later to accommodate us along with others who were seated for late lunch. Between the four of us, we split the calamari (heads up, this appetizer is not fried), a pizza, and two pastas. We ordered the radiatore from the daily specials and it was absolutely phenomenal. The pasta was handmade and presented in foil, served piping hot. I can't recall which pizza we had, but based on the crust, I'm sure they're all fantastic.Would love to go back and try some more of their dishes!

One of my AA fav's.  The ambiance is great especially sitting upstairs but the rails as you feel like your overlooking a palazzo in Italy. The drinks are well made and can be creative, many topped off with prosecco. The bread flies to the table once seated along with a nice bottle of EVVO to soak up.  I can't say enough good things about the bread, wherever you go on AA your in bread heaven.For staters, try the special grilled Octopus, we also had the mozz and tomato salad.  For entrees there were several great pasta dishes around the table that set off ooos and ahhhs.  One pasta dish prepared in a tinfoil tent which I thought was pretty cool. I had the special Mediterranean Sea bass with clams in a light (and great for bread dipping) sauce steamed in tin foil as well.Dessert was a beautiful piece of Italian cheesecake with just a touch of candied fruit found throughout- perfect!  There was also a sweet and crunchy cannoli that we all shared along side a few capaccinos.Lastly, let me add that our waiter Limo  was really great, attentive, knew the menu to a tee and did a great job exploring all of the specials.  This is my go to place on Arthur Ave and after several years of dinners here it was finally time to write this long overdue review. Update: 1/26/19 - another amazing meal. Shout out to Limo and his cousin behind the bar!  Best in class service, great food, great ambiance at ZON.  This is what all restaurant should be!

Absolutely fabulous dining experience. We went for lunch and all the plates that passed looked great and smell even better. The wine selection is extensive with lots of offerings from many regions. Wonderful service, yummy pizza, and lots of reasons to return.
The Best restaurant in nyc . They have the best servise , fresh food as well . You should try it I recommend for everyone!!! Enjoy

Very disappointing used to think this restaurant was one of the good ones left... now food is just okay depending on what you order. Most concerning is the horrendous service. Waiters have no personality and it seems no restaurant experience. Constantly looking for someone and no one is available.

I am a girl with intense borough pride. Having grown up in Queens, my home and my life were both subjected to MUCH boroughism by my Manhattan-dwelling comrades. My favorite places are all in Queens. But like all good little NYC urbanites ought to, I try to experience life in other boroughs. Like the liberal arts kid that I am, I thrift in Brooklyn; Like a good little musical theatre nerd, I see shows in Manhattan; like a lot of people, I don't really care for Staten Island. But the Bronx? Just wait.First, let's talk generally about Arthur Avenue. For those of you who are as unfamiliar as I once was, Arthur Avenue is the hub of Little Italy. Walking down the street you can smell crackling breads, biting espresso, fresh mozzarella. Its a fantastic area I wish I had known about sooner. I made the trek over to the Bronx's Little Italy I did not regret it.But the highlight of my lazy, gluttonous tryst with Arthur Avenue? Trattoria Zero Otto Nove. My mouth is salivating just REMEMBERING the food I ate here. The pizza was paper thin and perfectly sauced, but it wasn't even the main event! I ordered 2 pasta dishes in addition to my small pizza (as well as a healthy helping of free bread) and honestly, if I wasn't in public I would have licked my plate clean. Even the atmosphere was lovely. Lofty stone ceilings, cozy round tables, and a wonderful staff. I would come here again, even if it means temporarily betraying my favorite borough.

Let me start off by saying I've been to this restaurant multiple times as the food is amazing - only reason why this review gets two stars instead of one is the food. We come here, party of seven for my dads birthday. Food is good - until someone in my party finds a bug in her water. We call the waiter and tell him there's bug in her water. He immediately retorts "oh it might of of been from somewhere in the air *he points up* (haha). Not once he apologized, not once. He continued to tell us how the bug definitely flew in the glass of water - MIND YOU, THE BUG ISNT A FLYING BUG - we ask to speak to the manager. The manager repeated said story of said terrestrial bug flying in the cup. But he re-assured us he's going to make my dads birthday special. Fifteen minutes later, he arrives with a some pizza dough with Nutella smeared on (and powder sugar - oh joy!). Needles to say, these people do not know how to provide service. It's very unfortunately the fact I learned the true side of the servers as the food is worth noting here. Props to the cooks but please get rid of the arrogant servers.

If there is a rating below one star i would give it to this restaurant in a heart beat. Our waiter was very sarcastic and made a lot of witty comments that i am not here for. BUT WAIT THERES MORE. There was a roach in my water and once told to the waiter he shrug and said it must of fell from the ceiling. I called the manager and he seemed like he could care less also. Let's not forget that the speakers weren't working which is the only reason we came here for the infamous happy birthday song the ply bec it's my dad birthday. Oh and to top it off their plate are stupid expensive and all you're getting is 1 single item. Like my dad ordered the steak thinking it'll come with a companion considering the overly priced BUT NO, he got steak in a skillet. Hated everything about this place their service and food. Highly disappointed NEVER COMING BACK.
Best Italian style pizza in NYC.Thanks to Roberto for the nice experience today. The True Little Italy is in the Bronx.Highly recommended to everyone.

Love coming here. The staff is so friendly and helpful.  The beautiful hostess' are always polite and respectful. I was seated fairly quick. Although, I had to wait a bit I enjoyed sitting at the bar with well made cocktails. Love the food! Especially, the risotto ala pescatore. I have been coming here for years and will continue for years to come. The staff, food and ambiance is just remarkable!!

This is really a great Italian Restaurant.  I am Italian, and have lived in Italy. The food here is excellent. The service has always been five star.The waiters are very professional.  Don't expect a chatty waiter. They are clean and do what waiters do.  serve with a smile..The brick oven pizza is amazing.  Seating is always a bit difficult.  It is always full, lunch and dinner. But all the areas are beautiful. We love the center court yard, but the cozy upper floor is nice too.It's not over hyped. It's a NYC Italian Restaurant which is the best in the area. Like Italy, you don't eat Pasta with your main meal.  You order a Pasta, then a second course.  No "sides" in Italy!

I was very disappointed with the service this time around. I have been to this restaurant before and was very pleased with both the service and the meal. This time was different. Not only was my party passed around more than once to more than one waiter-but 4 different men were waiting on us at any given time. Other tables around mine were being served in a timely manner and without having to ask questions about their orders, I found myself having to do all the work myself. It felt like we were an inconvenience and the unprofessionalism was appalling. The wait staff showed zero interest in trying to please us, but instead passed around an infant child and ignored even the simplest requests (such as taking our drink order or giving us the check). This would not have been an issue during the dinner rush because understandably the volume in the restaurant would have been high, however we were one of the first parties to arrive right at 4:30 and didn't leave until 7. Save yourself $200 and go ANYWHERE ELSE in Little Italy but here.

Hostess was not friendly or nice, gave us bad looks and seemed as we were an inconvenience. The front part of the restaurant was empty and when asked if we can sit there, she replied that she was unable to put the tables together. Even though there was a table that would sit us all together. If it wasn't for the fact that we had traveled over an hr to go eat there, and being that we were on vacation from CO, we would've left. Once seated, it was better. Our waiter was fabulous and the food was amazing.

I can't say this experience was good because it was awful. My family and I showed up and the hostesses took their time seating us and when the host asked us to follow her, she walked way back to the end of the restaurant. I didn't get their seating arrangement. If we come in first, they should sit us in the front, not the dungeon in the back. The service was lackluster and I can't even begin to tell you about the food. I ordered the chicken parmigiana and it tasted like a slice of pizza and it was burnt. It didn't even come with pasta! What Italian place doesn't serve pasta with their chicken parmigiana?!  My son ordered the seafood salad and that was burnt too, my husband ordered the cavatelli and it tasted like cigarette smoke and it tasted old too. I have no idea how this place was so packed. I guess people ordered drinks first and never noticed how awful the food was. I took two bites of my chicken parmigiana and left it. Don't waste your money.

This place is beyond overhyped. Came here with family and the dishes were beyond cremated. I got some $30 grilled seafood dish and it literally was cremated. Plus it looked like it should've costed $8 instead of $30. No side or anything, didn't even come with pasta. First Italian place I go to that dishes don't automatically have pasta. Not to mention "grill" to them means "burnt". You ate it and literally tasted ashes.I thought I was on a prank TV show or something. I looked around and saw people eating Pizza, maybe the pizza is good, don't know because we didn't order any - and to add the chicken parm doesn't even come with spaghetti. Kind of wack.Other than that it's a beautiful interior I just wish the food could make up for it.

I give it 2 stars due to the horrible service. Wait staff is Albanian and they could all care less about service. If it weren't for my mother, he wouldn't have gotten a tip. Never asked if we wanted something to drink. We asked for bread, never got it. Never got a refill on my glass of wine. Shit, we couldn't even get out water refilled. He got annoyed when we asked questions on the specials. We saw him 3 times...when we asked for water, ordered, and check time. He would see our glasses empty, I would try to get his attention and he would walk away. We asked other waiters and they would give us a dirty look. Food was excellent but I would never go back due to that.

If someone of Italian heritage ever offers you a tour of Arthur Ave. in the S. Bronx, YES is the only brilliant answer. Recently, a professor of Sociology at Adelphi U and his fantastic spouse offered me a day in the S. Bronx. The highlight was Trattoria Zero Otto Nove. Reportedly the 089 name reflects the area code for Sicily. IDK. I don't' know. I don't KARE. This place is perhaps the best eatery I have ever set foot into and I've been to dine on several continents. I ordered a grilled pear and greens salad that was outstanding. The pears were actually warm too which added to the flavor. Then a simple four cheese pizza knocked me out. I love wood-fired pies but this one takes the cake. I cannot imagine ever imagine thinking about NY (my home state) without lusting for another visit.

I went here to celebrate my friend's birthday. I recently moved to the Bronx, and was delighted to learn that great restaurants like this exist in close proximity.  The menu was unique but very good.  The only downside is they don't have too many classic dishes, so my friend who came in thinking she would get traditional dish was out of luck.  However, they did have egg plant parm as a side dish and was delicious.  The decor of the restaurant was also very nice, vintage Italia. I would definitely recommend to a friend.

First time going and i had the chicken with pesto tomatoes just like everyone else said chicken was bland and flavorless but i had to try for myself maybe i would give it another try at a different time and revise my review

I can't say I'm an expert on Italian cuisine, I've visited Italy 2x for a few days each time and ate my way through. With that being said, this place always makes me feel like I'm back in Italy. It's so cozy and homey. The food is as close to Italy as you can get without buying a plane ticket. The staff is extremely knowledgeable and friendly. My fave is the squid ink pasta but the pizza is to die for as well. The interior is simple but elegant, you can come as you are or dressed to the nines. Parking is hard to find in this area depending on the day and time. Glenlevit 12 on the rocks for less than $10 is a steal.

This place is a hidden gem. It's like Italy once you go in. Service is always great, the ambience is so inviting and comforting. I have a great time every time I come here. The food is delicious and I tend to order the same thing although I did say to myself the next time I go I will try something new LOL but that has not happened yet. I always order the pasta puttanesca which never fails to excite my palate. It's a little on the salty side due to its ingredients, but I love it's robust flavor. I also order they're brick oven Margarita Pizza and it's always prepared fresh and fast. I definitely recommend if you want to feel like you've escaped New York and stepped foot in a quaint little restaurant space down an intriguing alley and Italy.

I'm really torn about this place because, on one hand, the food was quite good but, on the other hand, the service was absolutely terrible.My husband and I live in the area and have heard consistently good things about Zero Otto Nove so we finally made our way over there today for lunch. Things were off as soon as we stepped inside. Most of the front was empty with the exception of a small family so we figured we would be seated right away. Instead, we had to wait until a table opened up in the back of the restaurant which seemed strange but we assumed that maybe there was a party coming in. So we get seated, wait a minute for water that gets slammed on our table by a rather disgruntled waiter. Ok, we think maybe he is having a bad day. The tables around us are all families and we hear them being read the specials, having the menu explained, etc. while we wait, and wait, and wait for our waiter to come by our table. When he finally shows up, he didn't introduce himself, explain the specials, ask if we had any questions, nothing! We went ahead an ordered, our waiter leaves and then another waiter slammed down a basket of bread on our table. Seems like everyone is having a bad day! We got our pizza very quickly which was appreciated and it was delicious! Totally lived up to the hype. We got the Diavola with fresh mozzarella and spicy sopressata. Our mozzarella caprese came out shortly thereafter which was also quite good - fresh mozzarella from Casa Della Mozzarella down the street, canelini bean salad, tomato, and roasted red pepper. The food was really very good! Not that the waiters would know this because they never came to the table again to see if everything was ok or if we needed anything. The next time a waiter came to the table was to snatch the pizza plate off the table when it was empty. We were finally asked if everything was ok when our waiter came by to take our plates and refill my water glass that had been empty for most of the meal! We just asked for the check because, by this time, we just wanted to leave. Waiter said nothing when he dropped off the check nor when he returned it, nor when we passed him to leave - not a "thank you" or a "have a good day" - nothing!When we left, we saw that there were now people being seated in the front and there wasn't a party or anything going on there so I have no idea why we couldn't sit there when we first came in!So, was the food good. Yes, it was. The pizza was absolutely delicious. However, the service was so appaling that I will never come back here again - which is a shame because I live not far from here. I loved the food and the aesthetic of the restaurant , it would be a great regular date night place but the service just completely ruined it. This is Arthur Avenue - you can throw a rock and hit a great pizza place so you are going to need more than that to get folks to come back. It seems as if they are resting on their good reviews and aren't particularly intereted in customer service.

WONDERFULL EXPERIENCE, FOOD, AMBIENCE AND SERVICEThe food is very good traditional Italian fare.  Wait staff is top notch and the ambience in the back room is perfect - it feels like you are in a small square in Italy enjoying a real Italian meal.  This is why you come to Arthur Avenue.

We were looking for a new place to try something different.  I ordered the veal with prosciutto and eggplant. It was served as three medallions on top of red lettuce. I couldn't even eat it. The eggplant was thick and undercooked and the veal was thin and dry.  I was very surprised as this restaurant came highly recommended.  My husband had spaghetti with calamari and it was dry because there wasn't enough sauce over the dense spaghetti.  I would never go back. Very disappointed. Nobody even asked how our meal was. Overhyped and overpriced
Good pizza. Full Moon down the block is better but if you want a nice atmosphere, good pizza and excellent service then go here. If youre looking for a quick slice ala Joe's then go to Moon Palace.

A fellow Yelp reviewer felt I was too harsh and I now realize nobody stopped me from asking what prices were available.  However, it is difficult when you are with strangers as opposed to family. That being said, he is right about one thing.  One wants to see neighborhoods such as these thrive and the only way that could happen is if franchises there flourish. I respect and admire his passion. Where it not for SOME of the prices, this place is actually perfect.  Setting, speed of food delivery and quality of the ingredients.

Originally from Long Island, living in So FL the last 17 years, & we came to the Bronx to visit our son at Fordham. He's really acclimated, especially to Arthur Avenue, & took us on a walk down to find a place to eat. He'd never been to this particular restaurant. Walking in, the wafting of coal oven pizza warmly welcomed us. As it had just opened, we were seated immediately. The specials sounded amazing, so we started with the bracciole (a rarity in FL) It was just enough for us to each enjoy a taste. Without getting into specifics, this is not a pasta joint. Pizza was great, but the food ..... simply amazing. I had the short rib special & it was the best I have ever had. Tender. Tasty. Moist. 4 huge short ribs, & I nearly ate them all. My daughter has the chicken cutlet but wasn't used to something so much better than parm! Son had pasta forno & cleaned the plate. Dessert? Oh yes. Cream puffs. Nutella pizza. Everything was delicioso! The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is because the waiter never took our drink order. Either way, we have 3 more years of a kid at Fordham & will definitely be back to this restaurant. Molto bene!!!
Delicious homemade Italian food. Staff were very friendly. Food comes from local stores. Great atmosphere.

Amazing food. My friend introduced me to this restaurant and all I can say is WOW.  I ordered the grilled seafood and I was blown away. I was a bit nervous at first due to my dislike at some of the fish on the dish, like shrimp and scallops...but OMG...I would go back just for the shrimp!Nice wine by the glass selection, delicious bread...we couldn't go wrong. I look forward to going back :-)Nice decor, very busy place!

This was such a disappointment.  We went there with friends last Sunday night for dinner.  The service was terrible, and so was the food.  I was really looking forward to some kind of simple pasta dish.  Baked cavatelli with tomato sauce and mozzarella--how much easier can you get?  The cavatelli was hard, the dish was over baked, and there was very little mozzarella at all.  Two other people ordered the branzino.  They filleted it for us even though they at first said they wouldn't.  My husband's fish tasted and smelled fishy, so he left half of it.  The other person ate it but had nothing positive to say.  The fourth in our group ordered a simple chicken dish and said it was pretty good.  We'll never go back there again.  And it doesn't seem like they care.
Nice scenery the hanger steak was on the chewy side and the spicy meatball appetizer with polenta and goat cheese was  very good !

My second visit, this time on Laborday weekend.  Doors open at 1PM not sooner, even if you just want a drink at the bar, which is disappointing since there aren't many places to wait while this place opens up.Service and food is above average.  One experience that could have made this a 5 star: My wife is gluten intolerant and ordered the pasta al forno, they brought her pasta with sauce and melted cheese; we should have sent this back.  If you don't have gf pasta al forno, that's ok, but penne with sauce and melted cheese is not pasta al forno.Great wine selection, we had the only Umbrian wine on the menu, solid choice.Yes we will be back.

The chicken parm was as big as my face, the pasta was homemade and delicious, and the service was second to none. I am constantly finding an excuse to go back to the BX for the best pasta I've ever had.

Wonderful ambiance. The restaurant itself is really cool and takes you back to Italy in such a cool way. The food is great too. The menu has classic dishes but also some different dishes as well that are spins in a classic dish. Also they have dishes from all over Italy not just southern Italy. Definitely worth the visit. It's a little pricey but worth the splurge if you are celebrating.
There was plastic in my main course that was $30. They comped me a $5 dessert. The server avoided our table for 20 minutes. Over hyped and over priced.

We stopped here for lunch before our tour of Fordham. Most definitely a hidden gem! So many good options on the menu it was hard to choose. I ended up ordering from the specials that day, but would definitely go back to order off their main menu. Servers were incredibly friendly and helpful! I recommend sitting in the back area of the restaurant if possible, the decorum places you right in Salerno. With a sky light featured as well, it was gorgeous on a sunny day.

I loved the atmosphere and the waiters are so attentive. My friend and I shared everything and we were struggling with getting the pasta on the plate and the waiter came over and helped us out lol. There special appetizer for the day was so delicious friend asparagus with prosciutto and cheese  -- it looked so good .... I couldn't even take a photo and it tasted even better. Yummy! The entrees were good too, the dessert was ok. Dessert isn't a must here!

This is a really great Italian restaurant that shouldn't be missed if you are visiting Arthur Avenue, the Bronx Zoo, the NY Botanical Garden or anyplace up in the Bronx!!  I had rabbit stew (which was great), but if you'd like more traditional fare, they have it as well as beautiful brick oven pizzas.

The butter-squash pizza is delicious and worth trying, the crust is still not the best I have ever tried though, could be better. One other thing, it's too loud, probably whoever was the interior design or architect didn't consider the echoing of the sound in the walls. Overall would visit again.
I love good wine and even better pizza. I was only in New York for the day and didn't want to travel to Manhattan for good pizza. The crust and ingredients were fresh and well paired.

We took my parents there for lunch and found the place spectacular. We felt like we were eating in a small bistro in Rome. Our food was delicious   here is what we ordered one special of the day which was homemade rigatoni with sun dried peppers lamb sausage and egg plant that was out of this world. Another one was risotto with two different types of beets which was outstanding Cavitellis that were baked with fresh mozzarella, and butternut squash pasta. Portions were not small but not overly generous but the quality of the food is excellent. Four of us with all having a meal no appetizers no dessert and only one beverage was $100. Food was exquisite. My only complaint was our waiter he never smiled whatsoever. We almost felt like we were putting him out. This however did not detract from the quality of the food. My only suggestion is to talk to the young waiters and tell them to give a smile or two.

Fantasic food and service. We visited on a Saturday afternoon. When I searched for restaurants on Arthur Ave, this one was the most popular restaurant so I was afraid we had to wait but the wait was only 10 minutes. Arthur Ave wasn't too croweded either. Although it seems a bit touristy but unlike touristy restaurants, food was excellent.Italian is my favorite food, so I have tried a lot of pasta/pizza. This restaurant was a bit unique from other typical Italian restaurants with unique items on their menu. Brick oven baked pizza is very chewy with sweet pumpkin puree which I have never seen anywhere else. Rigatoni is double the size of any other restaurants. The food is on a salty side but it's bearable. I will definitely try to visit the one in Gramercy as well although the menu is more expensive.

Ok nothing great or special. Very very loud   Service was not very good.  Our waiter basically disappeared after our food came up. I would not return and I'm actually starting to doubt Yelp as a source of insight after this pic. Wish I went to Enzos.
This is our go to spot, when ever they have pasta specials cooked in aluminum foil you have to try it. Fresh pasta at its finest.

Everything we had was delicious! Pizza was perfect, pasta dishes homemade with interesting and tasty combinations, meatballs with polenta amazing. The Nutella pizza dessert could have easily fed 4 (although the pastiera was for us just so-so).
My memory of this Italian restaurant was epplant Parmesan appetizer, was delish. I would recommend it without a doubt.

I love this restaurant. The food is consistently amazing. The three stars is all about the service. Not that it was awful. But it was not good either. For example, while telling you the specials the waiter kept yawning (I did not order a special) or when ordering drinks we kept reminding the waiter that he had to get everyone's drink order, not just take the wine order and run. My personal favorite was the dramatic response to a request for an extra plate "you want another one?????" Was whined at us. Also is it unusual to request grated Parmesan in an Italian restaurant?  Is that a thing now?  Because the waiter was completely surprised by our request. Again food was delicious and well priced. I will most likely return. But wait staff could use a little training.

This was my first time at Little Italy in the Bronx and, realistically, my first time doing anything in the Bronx. Little Italy is quite concentrated, and it seems like the whole of Arthur Avenue and surrounds is full of good Italian restaurants. The person who brought me here says that there's so much competition that basically anything that's still open is probably pretty good. As we walked, a promoter tried to get us to come into another restaurant. There was a wait at Zero Otto Nove when we arrived, so we sat at the bar; we were told 30 minutes, but it was more like 15. Then a table opened up in the dining area. Apparently there used to be a piano somehow strung up in the dining room, which is no longer there, but the dining area is still cozy without being overly packed-in. I've started feeling clumsy when I eat out in downtown Manhattan, because it's so hard to fit through the tables to get to my seat. That wasn't a problem here. We ordered a Margherita pizza and a Mafalde con Broccoli di Rapa. Both were delicious. After the plentiful bread and olive oil that came as an appetizer, we couldn't finish the pasta, and it made a delicious lunch the next day. It was cheesy but not dripping in oil and the broccoli was just the right texture. I would definitely come back here, or bring visitors to the city.

Great dining experience. I love Arthur ave for italian fare. The short rib was so amazing!  So was the pizza. But that short rib though so perfectly tender and flavorful. The service is great too. Our glasses were never left empty.

I came in and was greeted by a charismatic ambiance! The hostesses Kristina & Daisy were so nice to me and treated me and my friends so kindly! The food was great and the hostess even came to check in on us and make sure we were enjoying ourselves. It was a great experience and i will be definitely be returning.
Food:Amazing!  Staff: Friendly  The only bad thing is that it can get a little loud.

I was a little disappointed by this place which initially seemed to be well recommended. After a short wait at the host stand, we were escorted through a walkway and then upstairs to the second level of the restaurant. Once seated, our waiter explained to us what the specials were and made some other recommendations. I ordered the short ribs, my boyfriend ordered the pancetta pizza. We also ordered a seafood salad and a glass of wine. The seafood was way overcooked, a little rubbery and really didn't taste too fresh. When the wine arrived it had come in an absolutely filthy glass. The short ribs were really chewy, not fall apart tender, although the sauce was good. The pizza was good too but a little on the salty side. Would not return.

I would give it a 3 plus. Walking into the restaurant you come into a small bar area which does not give the actual restaurant justice. You walk down the narrow corridor which opens to a large, high ceiling room with a balcony overlooking the lower large dining room.  The restaurant is beautiful and upscale . The service was good. And the food was tasty.  The negative is that it was pretty pricey. $29 for fish with nothing  else on the plate , no side dish. We ordered Brussels sprouts for $10; and it also was small Brussels sprouts and small order. Pizza was good . Noise level was very loud, so don't go there is you want to really talk to someone.i Gus's high due to the high ceilings, without proper acoustic tiles . Anyway, I don't think I will be going back due to the plethora of great Italian restaurants in the area, that give you more great food!

Went to the Arthur Street area for dinner before a Yankee game while visiting NYC.  Zero was the #1 recommendation of many people so my son and I selected Zero for our pre-game dinner.  The recommendations did not disappoint.  Zero was a good as they said it was.  We got there upon opening around 4:30 and by 5 the entire ground floor area was full and they began seating people up on the upper level.  While looking over the menu we saw the pizza's coming out to the tables around us, it looked amazing and the people quickly finished the pies, but we were going to Julianna's the next evening so we did not want to order pizza.  We started with the Calamari alla Peperonata, Sauteed calamari with yellow, red peppers, black olives & capers and also had an order of the Parmigiana di Melanzane, eggplant parm.  We shared these as well as our main dish, Pollo Capriccioso Breaded chicken cutlet baked with fresh mozzarella, Marinated tomatoes & pesto.  Everything was so well prepared and delicious.  The only complaint was I wish the chicken dish and a little more pesto and fresh mozzarella.  We both totally enjoyed our meal and will be back the next time I am in NYC for a visit and a Yankee game.

We love coming here. The food is always amazing, never disappointed.  The pizzas are perfectly cooked in a brick oven, you can see it as they're making it depending on your seat.  The service is impeccable. But if you want to experience this Bronx treasure, you might have to wait to be seated. There are no reservations.  Note: when I'm downtown, I go to their sister restaurant by the same name, located on 21st street.  All the same, except they accept reservations.

We were expecting a wait and immediately got a seat around 6:30 on a Saturday evening. It was the weekend before Fourth of July The decor is great, manages to make me sentimental about a place I've never visited. Started with a pizza margherita. Sauce was vibrant, crust was deliciously tangy from a light char, cheese was flavorful. I ordered the linguini with calamari and cuddle fish, with a tomato sauce. This was the most tender I've ever head calamari. My wife had the pasta al forno, the rigatoni were cooked amazingly, the meatballs and other toppings were just exploding with flavor. We got a side of broccoli rabe, which was to die for and much less oily than other Arthur Ave spots we've been to. Absolutely cannot wait to come back.
Great food and menu. Lousy service. Only one waiter who spoke English well enough to take orders in a very brusk manner. We spent a lot of money and we're not treated as well as we should have been .
Excellent food    Definitely I recommend a good taste of Europe taste ...!! Excellent service,  high quality of food .!

Pizza was really good, bread came second. Grilled seafood plate was mostly inedible (frozen octopus/squid lacked flavor and tasted like rubbery plastic). Food came out at the speed of light on a Saturday evening. Would come back but stick to pizza and pastas.

This is the second time my husband and I dine at this restaurant. First time the food was great, but the waiter was very arrogant and rude and didn't want to be asked questions about the menu or specials that night. The quality of the food outweighed the waiter's attitude that night, so we decided to give it another shot. This time both the food and the waiter (different waiter)were awful. We waited for at least 30 min to get the salad, and another 40 min to get our entrees. The food was rushed, wasn't cooked well enough, and it was abruptly dropped on the table by the waiter before he rushed to serve another table. We were looking around to find him and ask for utensils and pepper but he disappeared, so we had to ask the busboy to help. He didn't come back during our meal to check if we needed something. When we asked for the bill, he also threw the bill fold on the table and kept walking without saying anything. We felt very disappointed with this robotic impersonable level of service we received as guests. The place is a little pricy, we don't mind the price as long as we get a good level of service. Both experiences were bad with these 2 waiters that made our dining experience unpleasant and hard to digest.
Not at all kid friendly, the server made sure we wait the longest before any table is given to us, waited more than an hour, even when many people who came after us got the table before.
First time there but really enjoyed the meal and the ambiance. The decor is really interesting, it gives you the feeling of eating al fresco in the streets of Italy. Will definitely go back!

This place was fabulous! The hostess got us in faster than expected. The bartender didn't mind if we sat at the bar for drinks while we waited, even though he could be seating people there to eat. Everyone was so nice. The ambiance was gorgeous and you feel like you're in Italy! The service was fast but not too fast. The food was amazzzzzzing. And we've been totally loyal customers to Antonio's Trattoria nearby for a long time. Now we'll be going to both!

Very disappointing. Waiters were very bland and not that attentive. Good bread, good appetizers but the spicy chicken on the bone was fair at best. The pasta al forno was pretty good but really nothing special. The breaded baked chicken with bruschetta was the best entree. Two entrees had to be sent back because they weren't hot. Both cappuccinos were sent back also not hot.   All in all, fair at best. If we weren't already in the Bronx, it was no way worth the trip for the near $100.

Came here after being turned away from another Italian restaurant that wasn't accepting walks ins on a Saturday. Cute interior themed like an Italian courtyard. Both dishes we had were very good but not quite as good as what we've had at neighboring establishments.
My go-to spot whenever I'm near Arthur Ave. Food is always excellent whenever I'm here.
Simple put one of the best restaurants I've dined at.  Food was simple,  good ingredients,  treated with love which shows in the presentation and taste.  Service was impeccable.

I had my eye on this establishment for a couple of years. Yesterday had an opportunity on the way back to CT from the city. First encounter as I walked in. and waited for my friend to park, was a family whose son had just graduated from Fordham, however the father was drunk. He kept loudly rambling on and on (actual graduate wasn't there, I wonder why). Front desk girls kept talking to him, which egged him on and was very obnoxious. Finally they were seated, not sure why it was before us. Finally brought to a table and given the menu. I asked what the specials were today. They wouldn't tell me. I asked can you tell me because I would like to know BEFORE I look at the menu. Why should I go through the menu when I might want a special? They still would not tell me several minutes later. I flag down somebody else and pressure them. Finally get the information.I decided that I wanted to get the rigatoni with butternut squash purée, however wanted meat on the side. I was told that that was not possible. Why is that not possible? "The kitchen won't allow it." Well why? "Because it might make the dish taste different." Well that's what I want. No, we can't do it. Waiter finally said I could have shrimp on the side. I don't want shrimp. I meanwhile order wine and an appetizer, polpette (meatballs) with polenta. Wine was warm and appetizer was lukewarm. I sent wine back and was given another lukewarm glass.Meanwhile tried another waiter going by and asked what kind of meat I can get with the pasta. This waiter said chicken. I said what about beef. He said no, he couldn't do that. I asked for the manager. The first waiter comes back. I said are you the manager? He says yes, which I don't believe because he had the same outfit on as the other waiters and looked to be in his 20s. He said he could absolutely not add beef,  I would have to get another entrée. I said I don't want that much meat. He said that he couldn't do it.My friend meanwhile ordered escarole and bean soup which he stated was watery and bland, with San Pellegrino water. Water arrived in a generic bottle that looked like it it was a grocery store brand.So I ordered the rigatoni to go, we packed our bags and finished the night at Morrone's pastry shop two doors down, where at least I got a decent cappuccino and tart.This place is out of control!

Gorgeous place in the middle of bronx Italian neighborhood!! From outside you can't see anything, but when you enter the restaurant through a long hallway you feel you arrive to Italy! The painting on the walls and the decoration simulates an Italian street in a perfect way, and also the music! Pizzas were delicious, good price and very good service too.

I love Arthur Avenue!!!! I've been to a few restaurants in the area but this one was by far the best. My friend and I went to an event at the botanical gardens and knew we wanted to hit up Arthur Avenue for some dinner afterwards, she had been here before so I trusted her recommendation. We were seated right away, walking from the front to the seating area was super cute. It was like walking through the streets of Italy and the back area was like a cafe/outdoor setting even though we were inside. I wish I had taken pictures of the interior. They started us off with some focaccia bread and olive oil which was great, as an appetizer we ordered a caprese pizza and it was delicious! The crust was thin, the fresh mozzarella, tomato and basil was delicious. For an entree I ordered one of the specials, the beer braised short ribs with roasted red and yellow peppers. The meat was tender, the sauce was amazing though I could only eat a little because we were stuffed from the bread and pizza so I took the rest home and it was even more delicious as leftovers. My friend also ordered one of the specials, pasta with green pea puree and radicchio which she said was good. We were too stuffed for dessert but it looked like they had a nice selection. I absolutely need to go back and try some more of the menu, I would definitely recommend trying this place out if you're in the area, and if you're not in the area get there ASAP!

Wow. What a great place!Short wait on a Saturday night without a reservation. Nice hosts (which is so rare nowadays!) Tried the pear drink which was amazing. Had the Margherita pizza to start. This was the highlight of the night. I wasn't sure what to expect but I guess I should have geared myself up for it since we were on Arthur Ave. The crust was soft but crunchy and warm. The sauce was sweet and the cheese was fresh. Wowza. I had the ink pasta with scallops and my partner had the chicken parm. The chicken was delicious. It was breaded chicken with a kind of bruschetta mix on top. Only criticism... was wish there was more cheese on top of the chicken! We shared the strawberry dessert and AMAZING cappuccinos. Recommend 1000%! We will be back.

Came in today , haven't been here in awhile, Food was good(not great) but the waiter staff were rude/ unprofessional. We were offered water but never asked if we wanted drinks. When it was time to order ,a person in my party was ordering and he cut her off mid sentence with a" yeah OK "response and yanked the menu out of her hands. When we asked him if we could order drinks he rolled his eyes like he was doing us a favor.When the food came out a person at my table noticed half way through her meal that there was a big chip in her plate. We mentioned it to the wait staff and their response was "ok" with the what do you want me to do about it look. Then towards the end of our meal they kept coming by trying to rush us out the door never asking if we wanted more drinks or if we needed anything else. At the end of it all not a great experience. For the money your spending you should feel welcomed and not rushed in and out like cattle. The place feels like a tourist trap. The food is good but theres restaurants on that block that are just as good so nothing is lost if I never go back.

Is this place for real?  No matter when I show up, weekday, weekends, noon, 1 pm or 2pm, they always claim they are fully booked, including times when the restaurant is completely silent and empty.  Either it is a money laundering outfit or they hate single diners..

Must try the Cirilo Pizza - i would never have thought that butternut squash purée would be delicious on Pizza but there you have it. Also the polenta and meatballs appetizer is phenomenal. The best thing about this place is the totally different ambiance. It feels like you are entering a secluded grotto or hidden cave and then the room opens up to gorgeous high ceilings. Loved it. The blueberry pomegranate cocktail was also a plus. Would definitely recommend/ and/or go again.
Zero Otto Nove is seriously the best restaurant in Arthur Ave. Every dish is splendid and the servers are fantastic. I come here quiet often and it just gets better and better.

Very good! Servers were friendly and helped to navigate the menu. Mussels were delicious. The tomato sauce was sooooo good. Even after all mussels were gone I ate the sauce like soup. My whole branzino was good, but could have been WAY less boney. There were so many bones that it wasn't as enjoyable to eat...the fish was tender though and flakey. I just wish I didn't have to compete with bones...otherwise really good! The ambiance was very nice. It's almost shocking how big the place was. Loved the rustic Italian vibe. Great food all around.
This is by far my favorite restaurant on Arthur Ave. service is great, food is wonderful and they have Nutella pizza!!

This is a review after my 2nd time eating there.  This time I sat at the bar to eat and although the bartender makes for a great waiter never again will I sit there. The level of people gawking while they wait to be seated is obnoxious while you're eating.  It's a very rustic Italian place with terracotta-esque wall decor, wall murals and a cute little old Fiat usually out front.  They have cute little bathrooms which however only accommodate 1 at a time but are cute nonetheless.  There's highchairs for the kiddies and there's  upstairs and downstairs seating in the main dining room.  Kitchen closes for dinner prep so be mindful of that if you go.  Food wise no real complaints, the pizza is great, cocktails are yummy if not pricey and the dessert is delish (I tried the tiramisu and cannoli) and the service is good as well.  In summary go and try something in the BX.  Arthur Ave is buzzing constantly and is still very old school Italian with markets and restaurants. Show the Bronx some love.  There's limited street parking but there are a few lots available.

Love this place. I've had mixed experiences at other places on Arthur Ave but this place always delivers. The dining room alone is a destination,  with high ceilings and faux old world Italian decor. Service is always spot on and the food ranges from good to excellent. My go to whenever I visit the NYBG.
We went there after the Orchid Show at the NYBG for a late lunch,  everything is so good, the staff were super friendly!  Great place, great food!

Arthur Avenue is a slightly more authentic tourist trap compared to "Little Italy" (check the demographics there lately?) or other neighborhoods around the country that rely on a manufactured aura of authenticity and ethnic nostalgia to draw in crowds, often with food. (For a trenchant critique of this discourse, see the political scientist Adolph Reed's "Three Tremes," a devastating critique of David Snorefest Simon's Treme show: nonsite.org/editorial/th…) But what the hell -- even if you know it's marketing, it can be fun, and it can be tasty, and Zero Otto Nove (ZON) had plenty of all three. This is a cut above the white tablecloth stuff along the rest of Arthur Avenue, and it's not coasting on reputation like some of those places. Yes, there's still some Italian restaurant pageantry, but the list of specials is thankfully kept to a minimum (versus the 15-point list at some places I've been to.) Pizza is to die for. You can split it with a party, in our case 3, as it's six slices, and use it as an appetizer. We also had short rib (problematic price to portions ratio, srsly), calamari (bleh, my pallette [sp] is too used to breaded covering), and meatballs (UNBELIEVABLE but also bad P2P). For entree, I had a cavatelli (tomato sauce, basil), which was too conservative a choice on my part. I was really craving tomato-ish stuff, but frankly, I could have made this at home, and you should branch out to the more unusual stuff. I definitely couldn't have done the pasta, though, which was delicious. One minor problem: the stuff comes out way too scorching hot. It took me 15 minutes before I could really plow in; by the time I did, the 20 minute countdown your stomach does before it realizes it's "getting full" had only 5 minutes left. Ugh! That made it a struggle to get down and eating the cannoli for dessert really hard. Cannoli is dyno-mite, by the way.It's uneven, and the P2P is not good, but the good stuff (pizza, meatballs, pasta itself) warrants a visit, for sure!!!

Authentic Italian Cuisine @ it's Finest. The brick oven pizza is amazing, more of an appetizer. The chicken scarpiello is just the right taste of spicy. My go to dish is Chicken Capricossa, which is similar to Melanaze. The chicken is better every time I'm there. The fresh Arugula & fresh shredded cheese make this dish even more enticing. The waiters are extremely helpful & will go out if their way to make it a great experience. As always, the Peroni is ice cold & a must. I've been eating on Arthur Avenue for close to 30 years & this place is my #1 spot to visit. It's first come, first serve & is worth any possible wait. Buon Appetite!!

Came here for a romantic dinner. The food, service, and ambiance were all absolutely delightful. We were sat down after a short wait on a busy night. The servers continued to bring water, clear the table, and provided consistent service throughout the night. We had the margherita pizza to start, I ordered the mafalde con broccoli di rapa, and a chocolate cake to end the dinner. I was really pleased with the taste and presentation of the food. Left a full and happy camper.

Great food, great ambience. Only reason i didn't give a 5 star rating was b/c the Bronx location doesn't take reservations which isIs a little annoying considering their others locations do. Also, during our initial wait at the bar they're were two fibers/debris floating in my cocktail. Although, the bartender remade my drink, he was not apologetic nor was I offered any compensation. Other than that, food dessert, and espresso were delicious. Attentive wait staff.

My first time here on a date night on a Friday. No reservations so wait time was only 15min. Based on reviews we were expecting a longer wait and was prepared for it because others said it was worth it. So we had a drink at the bar until we were seated. Staff was pleasant and professional. The food was worth any wait, it was delicious. Very presentable and was happy with everything. Overall, I would go back again to try more dishes.

Delicious homemade pasta ! Run don't walk !!!One of my favorites on Arthur Avenue.  I have tried most of the restaurants here  but the food at zero Otto Nove  trumps all.It's truly a slice of heaven. When you first walk in there's a Narrow path and then transformed into  mini  Italian courtyard with high ceilings. You really feel like you're in a special place. We always sit upstairs which I prefer. It's a little quieter up Stairs so you overlook the diners below. You can only order what's available on the menu but they can make exceptions. The chef here is by  far the best and the homemade pasta is scrumptious. There's always an item for everyone to enjoy. Well worth the prices and the wait. The staff is good and accommodating. I wouldn't say exceptionally friendly but I have no complaints.  Parking is not too difficult so plan ahead with a big party. Bar none this is the go to place.

Great place. Sat upstairs which I liked. Less noisy and crowded up there. Wait for a table can be long so you have to go in there willing to accept that otherwise it will be a miserable time for you. The food is worth the wait however. I will go on the record as to saying I like the Manhattan location better for many reasons but this place didn't disappoint too much at all. I enjoyed the apps, pizza and pasta. The main meal I didn't care for too much I got the chicken scarpiello. Chicken was a bit undercooked for me. My wife and I agreed that from now on we will just focus on pizza, pasta and appetizers here. I think it's the right way to go.

Ambiance is "Italy constructed." I get it, you don't stumble upon a beautiful courtyard it feels like Greektown in Detroit for those that have been. Different was the lack of seniority and oversight that I have come to expect from most Italian restaurants I've been to. Lot's of teens waiting tables gossiping.Service was fine just not great. Food was also fine but not great. Wine was great but expensive.We'll skip it on the next trip.

In an area with so many amazing restaurants, I would still visit this one over and over.It is very unassuming from the front, but a walk down a narrow hallway opens up into a bright room with tall ceilings. My three companions and I ended up sitting in the small section upstairs, which was a little disappointing, but the food more than made up for it. We ordered a Margherita pizza as an appetizer, and it was perfect. Crispy but somehow still soft, saucy (but not overly), and covered in amazing mozzarella from the local Casa della Mozzarella. I talked about it for days after.Not really many vegetarian options, but I ended up getting the Antipasto Salernitano Caldo as my entree, which had stuffed peppers, eggplant, zucchini, and cauliflower, and it was delicious. My meat-eating mates were also singing praises of their own dishes.The wine and the service were also great. I can't wait to go back!

The. Best. Italian. Place. On. Arthur. Avenue.I know that's a gigantic claim, but Zero Otto Nove never disappoints.  We have been here as a couple, with friends and at large family gatherings and have always had an excellent meal.  The service is good, they have a nice wine list, and the food...is spectacular.  Their dining room in back is decorated beautifully as well.On most nights there is a bit of a wait, but it's worth it!

I was there about a month ago it's my 4th time there and every experience is beautiful service was amazing food amazing the hostess amazing can't wait to go back I had their special spicy pasta sauce with homemade pasta with Buffalo mozzarella like I said the place was amazing and I'm saying this with authority

I came here about 8years ago so I don't really remember what I ate. But I do remember that I enjoyed every single thing I ate. I also remember that the wine suggested by the helpful,friendly,attractive waiter went perfectly with what I ate. The atmosphere and decor was beautiful. I felt like i was in Italy. I want to come back soon and relieve the great experience I had years back.

This our go-to Italian restaurant. We've eaten here several times. Highly recommend the La Cirilo pizza (butternut squash puree for sauce, fresh mozzarella cheese, mushrooms, and truffle oil). All of their pizzas are made to order in the brick oven. Good stuff. There are specials that change all the time. We've never ordered anything that we didn't like.
There are tons of amazing Italian restaurants in Author Ave... This is not one of them.

Loved the atmosphere and the service. Classic little Italy feel, definitely more authentic than any Italian restaurant I've attended in midtown. Larger menu than I expected and very fresh ingredients!

Amazing pizza and atmosphere! What a gem!Went here on a double date with some dear friends and had a wonderful time. Service was excellent and the food is delicious; some of he best pizza in the area. Will be back!
Really, really, really, really good!!! Even the basic pomodoro sauce is ridiculous. I had a short rib special that was delicious. Great lively atmosphere and very nice wait staff as well!

Meh, does not live up to Arthur Ave standards.Food is bland. Service is not good. Ambience is terrible. Dark and old inside. Not clean. And they use the darkness to hide it. It's like a dungeon. Check your bill! Warning: The waiter did something weird. We shared the bill w/ our friends and gave 2 credit cards to split. He said 1 didn't work and brought back the bill all on 1 card w/o asking us first. I think they just didn't want to pay the credit card fee for 2 cards for a small'ish bill. You're supposed to let someone know if their card doesn't work and ask for another card or form of payment.  This place is not Italian. They are Albanian or something. I don't care either way but it's not what I expect from a so called authentic Arthur Ave restaurant in terms of service (unfriendly and unwelcoming, ambience (isn't any) and food (bland).Food:The pizza was lukewarm. It was soggy, not crispy and chewy - the crust was underdone. We got a pizza that was like a plain pie but w/ arugula. I forget the name. It was bland. I poured olive oil and salt on it. The side of broccoli rabe was ok. A little overcooked and bland also. My pinot noir was $9 and tasteless and odorless. Bread served w/ olive oil - wish it was served warm. You have an oven in the dining room - use it!ServiceNo one at the host/hostess stand on a Friday night. The bartender looked confused and came out to ask us how many we were. We were not welcomed we arrived and our server was not friendly at all. We said thank you like a million times and no answer. They didn't thank us when we left. No one spoke to us. Our server was non-existant.AmbienceIt's so dark inside. There is basically no decor. A few random posters. It's not clean. The dishes are old and dishes and silverware had smudge marks. Not clean. Bathroom was dirty (that means dirty kitchen).Weird odor when you walked in (cat litter). Floors had food on them. Where I sat was wet. 4 people2 pizzas1 side cauliflower ("w/ bread crumbs" - there were none on the plate)1 side broccoli rabe1 glass wine$40 w 20% tip

My friend just moved into the area. That's a win/win situation right there. I get to visit some amazing restaurants and I also have a friend in the area for good company. We visited Trattoria Zero Otto Nove for a little belated birthday dinner and apparently so did everyone else. This place is like the capital of birthday restaurant's in the Bronx. There were so many birthdays the night that I went it would be easier to tell you how many tables didn't have a birthday, or at least didn't announce it. I was unfamiliar with the Paul Anka birthday song as it was a little before my time but now I heard it so much I can't get it out of my head. Thanks for that one! The atmosphere is super cute. It's moderately loud on a packed evening with chatter from the tables and there's a variety of background music playing at a low volume. The lighting is relatively dim and romantic. Definitely a cool place to take a date. The service was legit. Our server explained all the dishes to us and even made recommendations. We trusted in him with some of our choices and he was so spot on. He stopped by frequently to make sure everything was okay and that we were happy with our dishes and boy were we happy!The bread is so good, soft crusty and super fresh. I ended up eating the whole thing. I honestly just could not resist. For our appetizer we went with the calimari which wasn't served the typical deep fried way. It was sauteed in a sauce and served with greens. The texture was good and the sauce was flavorful. It went well with my glass of chardonnay. For our main course my friend had the short ribs and she let me taste them. They were out of this world! Amazing flavor and tender too. She told me they were the best short ribs she'd ever had in her life. I went with the seafood platter which was presented very nicely with peppers. The shrimp were huge, the scallops were nicely toasted yet soft in the middle. The squid was a little chewy but hey it happens. All items are served ala cart so there are no side dishes so we ordered a serving of rigatoni ala vodka to share. The sauce was phenomenal. It was tangy but also salty and slightly sweet with a hint of cheese and super creamy. If they bottled that sauce up and sold it, I would definitely buy it! The portions were great so we were quite satisfied with our meal but managed to save a little room to share a dessert. We got the tiramisu and it was also delicious with very rich flavors. I have nothing bad to say about this place, our dining experience was top notch and I will most certainly be back. Oh one last thing.... "Did you have a happy birthday? Did you get the flowers I sent?"

This is my favorite spot on Arthur Ave for any occasion. The food is delicious (we love the pizza), the atmosphere is pleasant,  and the service is excellent. I usually bring visitors from out of town here to showcase what the Bronx has to offer!

I have been here twice and the the first time the food was amazing and the second time it was just ok. We ordered the eggplant appetizer and it came cold which set the tone for a sub par meal. The service is pretty good and I love the atmosphere- busy and bustling but also cozy.

If you like to eat Italian, make some noise and enjoy a bottle of wine with friends; this is the place to be.  Arthur Aves gem, open and airy great pizza and excellent service. Don't be fooled by the narrow bar entrance; You will not be disappointed.

Our group was seven adults and three children under five. We went for lunch on a Saturday and the food was AMAZING!!! I can't recommend it highly enough. All of the food was fresh and absolutely delicious. Flavor-forward, authentic and comforting. Will be back! Ciao!

Such a fan of this Italian restaurant on Arthur Ave. in the Bronx. My family always pairs this restaurant with a visit to the Bronx Botanical Gardens. There is always a long wait if you don't get there early, so I would strongly suggest getting there at 5pm (they don't take reservations as far as I know). The restaurant looks small, but it has such a beautiful open room once you go down the long hallway.I'm a big fan of their pizzas. Love their traditional margherita pizza and their potato pizza (omg it's so good!). We also always get their antipasti sampler (vegetarian) and their caesar salads are delicious. My sister  gets a cheesy pasta dish and my dad loves their eggplant parmesan. I've tried both and they are definitely worth getting.Finally, the best part of this restaurant is going when it's someone's birthday. They play a song over the loudspeaker and the whole restaurant essentially sings along. It's such a great vibe and highly recommend.

We had guests from California visiting and we wanted to show them the real Little Italy in New York, so came to Arthur Ave before visiting the Botanical Garden. We had a little bit of a wait at lunch because we had a large party (plus a baby). We were seated in the corner of the dining room, which was nice. The dining room has very high ceilings and a skylight so it's an attractive space. The food and service were great! Loved the creamy polenta and meatballs starter (we ended up ordering another!). We really enjoyed everything we had including pizza and soup, but especially liked the pork chops and the branzino.

We were exploring the Bronx and decided to get some dinner in Little Italy. This place came highly recommended so we went in. The wait was about and hour for our table so we decided to go for a walk and come back. Other places we checked had a 30/45 min wait anyways so we went back to Zero Otto Nove and waited at the bar. The bar area is a narrow passageway that everyone uses. We had to stand by the wall and be squished by parties being seated. But we were having some delicious wine so it was ok. We finally got a table after more than an hour. We were seated by the pizza oven - we watched the pies fly out at a good pace. The space is cute - faux Italian houses and a high ceiling which really makes the space work. Our waiter was great and gave us some suggestions. We started with the la riccardo Pizza. OMG it was amazing. Thin crust, nicely charred, butternut squash purée, pancetta and a smoked mozzarella. It was so good I wanted t keep eating it.  We had a seafood risotto - also amazing. Rice was moist and delicious and the seafood was cooked perfectly. The Ragu salernitano was a hearty meat sauce with a large meatball (yum) pork skin braciola, beef braciola and a sausage. The meet was great but the sauce tasted a little burned. We ended the evening with some espresso and an amazing, creamy cannoli. Loved our decadent dinner there.

I just finished one of the worst italian meals I've ever had here! From the poor job of hostessing to bad service to sub par meals to unimpressive wines (not to mention that everything is at a premium price) I was extremely disappointed. Each of the four people at our table said their dish was "meh" and not worth it. I thought so - my pasta al forno was meh to the max.

I ventured out to Arthur Avenue for the very first time and had the pleasure of sharing an impromptu weeknight dinner here with my husband. It was an absolutely delightful experience! I am admittedly unfamiliar with the Bronx. It may as well be Mars to this Queens girl. But, I will gladly concede that when it comes to authentic, quality Italian food, the Bronx has Queens beat.I can't say enough about how lovely the dining area is! It's a cavernous, open space with sky high ceilings. It's been carefully decorated to recreate the feel of an Italian piazza, with makeshift windows adorning the walls and plenty of candlelight to give it a particularly warm, romantic feel. We loved all the attention to detail and think their efforts were well worth the end result.Our server was wonderful. While I cannot remember his name, I can't say enough good things about the service he provided which was attentive without being overly intrusive. We ordered a Margherita pizza with anchovies to start. Everything about it was wonderful. Perfect start to our meal. Our server suggested an off the menu item for my husband, who wanted a seafood pasta. The linguine came in a lovely sauce made of seafood stock and a touch of cream, heavily adorned with a perfectly cooked medley of seafood. Also fabulous!My meal, a hanger steak topped with mixed mushrooms, cherry peppers, arugala and parmesan was my least favorite part of our meal. I found my steak to be chewy and didn't much enjoy all the acidity from the cherry peppers, nor was I fond of the mushrooms used. Make no mistake though; these were matters of my own preference. This meal would have made many others quite happy, but was just not suited to my palate. If I could do it over, I'd have ordered the sauteed veal with fava beans and dry ricotta. I'll save that for a future visit.We ended our meal with cream filled profiteroles in chocolate sauce. It was a sweet end to an even sweeter evening!
fresh and delicious dressings but Pizza is a little bit over-baked. Perhaps a shorter cooking time makes a better and healthier taste

It's worth the visit - place has a pretty remarkable reputation. I found myself to be both satisfied, and maybe slightly underwhelmed, but maybe just because of all the hype...Definitely a wonderful spot with delicious, home cooked Italian, but I don't know if I would need to come all the way back up to the Bronx for that. When in the area, will definitely try again, and would give the Flatiron location a try as well.

Great bar area and even better dining room with balcony overlooking pizza making area and oven.  Squid ink pasta with calamari is plentiful and delicious.  Arugula salad with shaved parm was beautiful and delicious.  Christian from Arthur Avenue Food Tours recommended this place.  It did not disappoint.
Delicious food, excellent service, big portions, comfortable environment, would highly recommend

3rd Arthur Avenue restaurant that i visitedWell the Martinis are AMAZING!!!! the food delish and the crowd coolIm a lover of little Italy in the Bronx and this place adds to my great experience in this area!! Will def be back!!!P.s them Martinis are everything

We came here on a Saturday night during Fordham family weekend without a reservation, and still were able to get in for a dinner without too much of a wait.  Looking in from the street you'd have no idea how much seating there is in the back of the restaurant.There is a two-story open area with seating that is set up to feel urban outdoors with exposed masonry and posters in Italian.  It is a fun place to eat, but it can be really loud there.  We were seated next to a boisterous group of 16 that delighted in long distance conversation.  If you are looking for more quiet you might try the bar or the upstairs seating.The food was excellent.  We had a Portobello appetizer with a little kick.  There was a short-rib special on the menu that was outstanding. We had mixed reviews on a chicken rustic dish with one thumbs up and one with less enthusiasm.Our server was very upbeat and fun.  He was enthused about the menu and helpful with questions and checked in regularly to make sure we were good.There are a lot of good restaurants on Arthur Ave - this is well worth trying out. We'll be going back.

Stopped in the other day for lunch after visiting the botanical gardens, and it was crowded for a weekday lunch, which is always a good sign, and after eating I know why!!!We got seated right away today for lunch around 1230/1. They even sat us at a bigger table because we requested. Service was excellent and friendly. The menu is awesome!! They have pizza as well as appetizers, salads, soups, pasta, steaks, veal, chicken, fish, and veggie dishes.
