The menu is so unique, unlike your typical Italian restaurant with chicken parm and fettuccini alfredo. Delicious, homemade, authentic Italian dishes. And the desserts are great too!Daily specials as well; my dad tried a special today with homemade rigatoni, prawns, clams, peas, in a delicious light sauce. Sooooo yummy. I had the cavatelli (so yummy and I have leftovers for tomorrow!) and my mom had the veal scallopini, which I tried as well, and was sooo good!!Definitely a new favorite spot on Arthur Ave!10/10 recommend :) if you're looking for a delicious authentic Italian meal, look no further!!I will most definitely be back!
Perfect place for a date night.Italian romantic vibe with nice decor.Friendly staff and quick service.Their pizzas are amazing, thin crust, great cheese.Ask to sit inside, Venetian style decor.
Have never ventured out to any other restaurant on the strip...Find no need to, whenever I'm in the Bronx this is the place I love to go.  Really great food and service.

After much discussion on what Arthur Ave restaurant to try before a visit to NYBG, we all settled to check out Zero Otto Nove. Showed up around 6:30 on a Thursday night and waited about 20 minutes for a table for 3. We started with the butternut squash and spicy pancetta pizza- unreal. I got their special seafood pasta with rigatoni, which I thought was amazing and the pasta was extremely fresh- cooked perfectly for my taste.  The birthday song they play is a hoot.Downsides- it's loud in there and I felt like I was screaming across the table. Service wasn't very quick and we waited a very long time in between our pizza and our main dishes.

I came here with some friends and the wait was long. I figured I've tried every Italian spot on Arthur avenue and this must be worth it.  It has great reviews. I should have gone to my favorite spot Antonio's Trattoria. Let's just say our waiter wasn't friendly at all. The food was just basic. It's wasn't bad but it wasn't worth the wait nor the price. My pasta was hard and when I told the waiter he said this is what "al Dente" is. I told him that the pasta was undercooked and not al dente. He offered us free dessert which was nice but he should had offered the meal as complementary. Again food wasn't bad but I have so much better.

La Riccardo (a pizza with squash sauce).This was recommended, and I am glad we had it. Great thin crust with chewy-and-crusty in one. The toppings are a little salty (prosciutto), so carefully choose your sides and the main. I wish I had a glass of dry white wine (but a glass of Pellegrino was just as excellent).Squid ink pasta.Excellent flavor. I avoid garlic whenever possible (because of the smell - it was a lunch!), but this is a dish that cannot do without it (and the chili pepper, of course). Dry white wine is a must (again I almost bit my nail for not having alcoholic beverage - again, it was a Friday lunch). Another must have.Profiterole.Italian cream puffs with chocolatey sauce on top. Real custard. Slightly crusty on the outside, buttery and chewy on the inside. Inhale the harmony of this olfactory joy, and then take a bite - it will get your five senses busy. Have a cup of Italian roast with no sugar to complement the sweetness of the custard. Share it with your loved ones!
This restaurant is delicious.  Impeccable service and amazing food. If you are in the New York area this is a must.  Authentic Italian at its finest.

Went on 4th year anniversary.The wait is insane. However, it's Arthur Avenue, so we knew what we were getting into.The atmosphere is dark and the staff lacks a little bit of personality, but the service was quick and the food was on point. I ordered the chicken scap and it was delicious. It is clear that the food they serve is cooked by very talented chefs. The food is aesthetically beautiful and tasty. Bring a sweatshirt though, it's freezing inside. With the sweatshirt, bring a date. It is a classy place that sets a romantic atmosphere for the entire evening.

My new favorite restaurant on Arthur Ave.  Nice bar in the front, beautiful dining room (very Italian looking and Italy vibe) in the back with a fairly extensive menu of old time favorites and more modern items.  Very friendly and efficient staff.  Started off with a nice Antipasto Freddo and for my main course had the Bistecca alla Salernitana.  Both excellent and the hanger steak portion was enormous.  Probably should be giving 4.5 stars but alas....   I hope to be back soon!!!

The food is very good- I have been here more than once but I will never return because our wait staff this evening  was Terrible Terrible Terrible. I will not get into the details. ( this happened upstairs on 9/22 at about 7pm )But he was unprofessional and condescending to say the least. There are other reviews here of terrible service  - so think again.

This is a gem located on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx.  It is less traditional than many of the other spaces, but the food is amazing.  The open area of seating in the back is breathtaking and the staff are incredibly attentive.  The pastas are truly wonderful.  Highly recommended.

Food is very good.  The real deal.  Fresh, looks great, taste delicious.  A little pricey but worth it. Staff stiff not attentive.  Work at the hospital a block or so away.  Outstanding.  Love the Nutella pizza for desert.

I was on Arthur Ave for a street fair which was way too crowded, so we escaped into Zero Otto Nove, and what an escape it turned out to be, like we time-traveled to a back Alley in Rome's Trastaverde to a quaint outdoor Cafe where we had light music in the background, great service and great smells coming from the large Pizza Oven in the Trattoria!  It was heavenly, as was the salad we shared followed by a wood-fired over Pizza, crispy, just the way I like it, then their Pasta al Forno, which was like a while Sunday diner in a personal sized Casserole dish, served "Piping HOT... be careful!".  It was a memorable meal.  one that I hope to repeat often!  I would highly reccomend this restuarant for anytime you want to impress your guest(s)!

Went here with a large group celebrating the ordination of Rodolfo Casals into the Jesuit Order. The atmosphere was fantastic and the meal was so very Italian. The wine was excellent and the staff were most accommodating every step of the way. I live in Tennessee and cannot get Italian food like this. It will be a first stop the next time I 'm in the Bronx. Highly recommend to all Italian lovers of fine food.

Went here for lunch. Nice ambience, decent but aloof service, good pizza. Stay away from the veal scallopini. When I first cut into the veal, I was sure that my knife was dull and was about to ask for another. But I persisted and used more elbow grease and I was able to cut through. Once it was in my mouth I knew right away that it wasn't the knife. I suspect that a Valyrian Steel blade would have served me better, but my teeth were no match for this veal. Truly the toughest I have ever eaten. The prosciutto that came with the dish was not much better. This meal sat in my stomach like a rock for the next couple of hours.Stick with the pizza.
It's a slice of Italy in the Bronx. Love the staff, food, atmosphere, etc. they seated a large party quickly and let us get a little rowdy too. It was fun!

I came here with my fiancé and her aunties who took us out to eat . The wait time was 1 hr on a Saturday evening so take in mind and also parking was a little tough but we found after 10 min, not bad. Also while we waited we walked around the stores and bakery shops which I loved! The bar bill is separate great Chocolate espresso martini a must to get!!! Over all the food was great Brick oven Pizza amazing and my dish was Pollo Caprissioso but did not come with spaghettis that's all I would say was not good ! The Parmesan chicken was huge so it would if  been nice to have some noodles and a smaller chicken! I love the Italians and service very nice and inside was beautiful!!!!!! Will come again!

This was a Yelp find. Little Italy is were you want to be for fine Italian wine and food. Our first stop while in The Bronx & we were blown away by not only the beautiful restaurant that looks to be the size of a shoe box but then opens up at the end of a hallway to a two story fairytale with a pizza oven and sky light. Margaritas and red Sicilian wine pair with a pizza to share and seafood risotto. This is a foodie dream come true.

I urge people to please read this review!!! If you care about the service you get PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE DO NOT GO TO THIS RESTAURANT.  All the servers who are only men give Horrible service. The food is mediocre you can get better pizza and AMAZING SERVICE at Fortina. I went to dinner there last night and got the wrong wine, there is a big difference between Sauvignon Blanc and Pinto Grigio. I ordered the salmon with Brussels sprouts and asparagus and never got the asparagus. When asked y I didn't get the asparagus none of the servers since my server never came to the table could give me an answer?!?!?

Stopped here for lunch on my first trip to Arthur Avenue and I did not regret my choice of restaurant.  To start we had the zuppa di vongole ($13 - Mediterranean clams w/cherry tomatoes & fresh lime) which was served with plenty of bread to sop up all of the clam juice.  For mains I had linguini alla puttanesca ($15 - tomato sauce, black olives, capers & anchovies) and my fella had the short rib special.  We had this meal about 7 months ago and he is still talking about how good his short ribs were, and he is not one to talk about food much.  He said it was one of the best meals of his life.  So I guess I am recomending ordering the short ribs if they are a special on your visit.  The linguini puttanesca was very good, if you are not a fan of anchovies I recommend asking them to leave them out of the dish, but i like eating this dish the traditional way so I powered through the anchovies.  The over all vibe of the restaurant is fairly cheesy as the walls are painted to look like you are eating in a town square in Italy, but some times cheesy is okay by me.

I came here for dinner on a Saturday night with my husband for the first time a few weeks ago. I thought the food was quite good, but I was disappointed because we thought they had fettuccine alfredo with truffles, based on many photos we had seen by other restaurant reviewers. We ordered a margherita pizza, clams, an arugula salad, and a pasta dish (don't remember the name of it but it had a red sauce and it had eggs and I believe sausage or another cured meat). I am only giving this restaurant 3 stars because we thought the service wasn't the best, and also because of the location of our table (a high traffic area). I also didn't like that the specials were not printed on paper because it was loud in the restaurant and we couldn't hear and remember everything the waiter had recited to us. After we got our appetizers, the rest of our food took awhile to come to the table. We weren't sure if the servers forgot about us, were just too busy, or if they were waiting for us to finish the appetizers. Regardless of the reason, I think they should have checked in with us because it seemed like they just forgot, so we just asked another server walking by about our food which he then brought to us. Since the food is very good, I would come back, but I'd rather return during a less busy time.

Pizza to die for. Staff is eh. I was expecting a more hospitable bunch. Don't order steak, it's a good attempt but the meat is tough. Don't go late, as they'll rush you out without asking about dessert or even checking back with you after your food is dropped off.

Beautiful space! You don't get a feel for the space until you get escorted through the hall. It's a must-see. Margherita pizza ~*   4/5The crust could have been cooked longer. Ratio of cheese to crust made it a bit soggy. I do appreciate the thin crust though. Breaded chicken cutlet ~*   4/5The portion was very generous. I shared it with my friend. The crust was perfect. As well as the tomatoes and pesto on top. HIGHLIGHTS:Spacious and beautiful interior Fragrant olive oilScrumptious rosemary, sun-dried tomato breadThin pizza crustKnocked off a star because the food got cold quickly. Also service was average. I found myself waiting a while to order.

Never miss an opportunity to dine here when visiting Arthur Ave.  Food is fresh and delicious with something for everyone.  The ambiance is lovely -looks like an outdoor grotto with the skylight adding just the right touch. Service is always excellent and prices are reasonable for the generous portions served. Go...enjoy..mangia!

The service is amazing. The food is incredible. I love every bit of this establishment, perhaps the best part is the fact that I can eat anything off the menu or a chefs special. Trying this place is not something to think twice about, you are definitely missing out if you have not already.
The pizza is really good &  the rest of the menu is excellent.The atmosphere is so beautiful & wait is worth it.

I hear that this is quite possibly the best Italian restaurant on Arthur Ave. In the strange event that it isn't the competition better come correct! I came here one evening to enjoy dinner with a friend. We waited not even a full minute before we were led to our seats. (No reservations are accepted) The decor and ambiance certainly creates the feeling that you're on one of the streets of Italy. I ordered Pollo capriccioso and my friend ordered a margherita pizza with a salad. As we waited for our food to come out we enjoyed the fresh bread. I was extremely satisfied with the quantity of chicken I received and the savoriness. I'm sad that this is the first time I visited but so happy to have found this restaurant.

I was looking forward to eating here for a while.  It is gorgeous inside and the service was fantastic.  The passion margarita was delicious, fruity,  and nicely strong.  My party tasted each other's drinks and I think after mine the next best was the expresso martini. The desserts were delicious.  I had the tiramisu, which was great.  The food,  however,  was disappointing.  The spicy meatballs appetizer's sauce tasted just like Chef Boyardee. My sister's dinner special of shrimp and mussels pasta was tasty but some shrimp were not properly cleaned and some had tails.  My husband had the Ragu Salernitano, which he said was good, but I thought should have had a side choice for the price.  A side of pasta or salad would've been good.  Finally,  I was not happy with the B restaurant grade.  I chose to ignore it but once at home I checked their record.  It seems quality has been declining.  This can only be blamed on management.  Quality standards should be met for the price being charged.  I won't return until I see that efforts for improvement are made. It's a shame because it is absolutely lovely in there.

Some of the pastas here are excellent - and things you don't often on other menus.  One in particular which is very good is malfade - the long fettuccine type with rippled edges, with chick pea and pancetta. I had the whole bronzino which was excellent, but it had way too much "sauce" - tomatoes and things, etc.  I'd have preferred it plainly grilled or broiled with just EVOO and lemon juice.  In general the food is fresh and nicely done, not gloppy or terribly over seasoned.  tiramisu looked good from what I can on another table - but we opted for desserts at the pastry Marrone pastry shop next door.  Service here is very good - professional and friendly. The wine list marginal, but prices are reasonable. Wish they had more good southern Italian selections by glass or bottle.   I never understand why most Italian restaurants - which are essentially red sauce places, and Southern in style, serve that insipid Pinot Grigio rather than a simple Orvietto or Greco di Tufo. My guess is they go for recognition factor over quality - they could sell the better stuff at the same price and make out better in margin - and people I think would enjoy them better.  All in all this is one of the better Arthur Ave places.

Probably the best pizza place for me. They have great entrees but the pizza stole my heart. I came here a few times and each time ordered the Ricardo and the Quattro Formaggi pizzas. MUST TRY! Butternut squash may not sound appealing for a pizza choice but it is GREAT! Will forever go back.

The reason I'm not giving this restaurant four stars or five is that I was not very happy with the service, the waiter was not very attentive and never came back to the table to check on us my food was delicious although I made a custom pizza I got one of their pizzas an added things to it and I loved it it was delicious my friend got a meal that she also loved and thought was delicious the dessert was extremely disappointing it was actually so bad we did not eat it when the bill came the person that took our designer way must've noticed that we didn't eat it and they never charged us for it which was very nice I would definitely come back again but hopefully the next time the service will be a little more attentive

service was above and beyond !The food on a late Saturday afternoon was old world Italian the way it used to be.Go there enjoy the atmosphere a bottle of wine with friends.  Fine dinning  it's not BUT light casual fun it is YES!

This is great restaurant food is fantastic the service and team is outstanding  they work together from the bartender to the waiters and host and staff..the atmosphere  is good and the looks of the restaurant.

The best Italian spot in the Bronx!! An Arthur Avenue institution, the Holy Grail of mouth watering pizza and pasta. Chef Roberto should be in some Hall of Fame, somewhere, sometime soon for his mastery in the kitchen!

I have been coming to Trattoria Zero Otto Nove a few times a year for the last few years while working at Fordham down the road and it never disappoints. This most recent visit was no different. This past Sunday, with a group of 8, we were seated right away around 7:15pm and greeted with terrific service by two different wait staff members who worked fluidly together. The environment of Otto Nove is pretty casual, and feels very Italian grotto-esque, with a high-brow bar space in the front, and a rock-formed and nicely decorated back dining room. We started with some wine, a red and a white, from their lovely wine list. The red had just enough tannin and great full body Italian flavor. I only tasted the white, but it seemed to have just enough power, yet enough refreshment to fit a summer evening.For food, we had two openers: the meatballs and two of the burrata specials. I really enjoyed the meatballs and how they played with the rough tomato sauce and delicious polenta. Burrata was a bit of a let-down and I probably wouldn't order it again. For my primary, I ordered the linguini al Nero di Seppia e Calamari with spicy black squid ink. The flavors were terrific and full, pasta was well-made, and the calamari and whitefish were prepared deliciously. I would've like it lightened up a little bit more, but otherwise it was great. Portions across the board were huge. I will definitely be back in the coming years when I am in the area!

Went here for a work outing on a Saturday. They were able to accommodate all 8 of us very quickly. The place seemed a bit magical. the outside does not do the decor and seating inside. the server was really nice and pleasant. He read us the specials, and then took our drink orders. I ordered the meaty pasta, and it was delicious. My partner ordered the short ribs, he said they were great. Over all the experience was nice and the prices were reasonable. Next time I am near Arthur Ave I will be sure to stop by again!
Popped in for a late lunch with a few colleagues after a stop at Yankee Stadium.  Excellent brick oven pizzas, salads, and homemade pasta.

This is literally the best restaurant on the whole strip. The decor is very unique and cute, it makes you feel like you're abroad in Italy. I've been here many times and I always want to keep going back. The service is always impeccable and they are always very attentive. The food in itself is scrumptious and always full of flavor, I've tried a lot of items from their menu and have loved every single dish. Their pizza is my absolute favorite! They make a big deal out of birthdays so this is definitely somewhere you can celebrate someone's special day.

After walking around all day at the Botanical Garden we were looking for the perfect spot to have our first Arthur Avenue experience. And this was it! We sat at the bar for just drinks and a pizza, and were so pleased with everything, including the fantastic service. Highly reckoned the Diavola pizza, but only if you can handle some heat! And the bread they served lived up to all Arthur Ave expectations. My only regret was not going there with a bigger appetite, because there were so many other incredible things on the menu we wanted to try. The pastas we saw going to other tables looked incredible, and the burrata looked so insanely fresh.

The food here is amazing. Had the topical plate penne vodka & my boyfriend had a plate of mixed seafood. The penne was so good we order another plate. The wine here is also amazing here. For dessert we had tartufo (my personal favorite) it was good. The bill came out about $80 which is great for all the food & alcohol we had.

Came here on a Sunday around 2pm for lunch with friends after visiting the NYBG . The atmosphere is beautiful and welcoming. The decor makes you feel like you're dining at a cafe in  Florence. The service was exceptional from start to finish and that's a big deal to me. Each staff member we came into contact with was friendly, warm and welcoming. Our water glasses were never empty and they always knew exactly when to come back to check on our table.The food is AMAZING. We sampled several pasta and seafood dished and everything was so well done. The portions are pretty big so you could definitely get a few things and share with your group. I will definitely be back!

Amazing experience. The atmosphere is great and the staff is wonderful.The focaccia bread (from the complimentary bread basket) is the best I have ever had. The regular bread in there is also great.We got the rigatoni al forno. See my picture because it is just as good as it looks. Highly recommend. It's easily shareable between two people along with the bread.

Amazing pizza we had the La Vincenzo which was very fresh and the crust was perfectly thin. It is reasonably priced and the ingredients are very fresh (the mozzarella is from our favorite Casa de Mozzarella). The only thing that turned me off was the B from the Department of Health in the window...

This afternoon, me, my son and his grandmother planned to go to Arthur Avenue for a day of shopping and enjoying a great lunch.  Our main purpose was to dine at Trattoria Zero Otto Nove since it received such good online reviews. We arrived on Arthur Avenue in a complete deluge of rain.  It took approximately 20 minutes of circling around the area to find a parking space 4 blocks away from Trattoria Zero Otto Nove. Finally, we arrived wet, but happy to be at Trattoria Zero Otto Nove.  It was 2:33pm.  We were prompted told, "Sorry we are closed for lunch." by the smiling woman at the front.  She said, "So sorry but you are 3 minutes late for lunch".  We tried to explain we didn't know that they were closing for lunch and we had drove all the way from Manhattan to eat there in the pouring rain. She did not budge. Then I asked to speak with the manager, thinking someone reasonable would understand our situation.  The smiling woman said, "Sure, I will get the manager."  30 seconds later, a very brutally, stern woman, stood in front of us and said, "There is no manager on duty, and we are closed for lunch.  I cannot make ANY EXCEPTIONS.  IF I MAKE AN EXCEPTION FOR YOU I WILL HAVE TO MAKE AN EXCEPTION FOR EVERYONE!"  I said, there is no one else here asking to be seated for lunch."  She said in no uncertain terms, "NO!" Really,.....had we come 3 minutes earlier we would have been seated!  "NO EXCEPTIONS!"   In the pouring rain! I have no idea what the food is like, so I can not comment.  We went to another restaurant down the street where the manager greeted us with a smile, seated us immediately, service was spot on and the meal and wine were delicious.

Yanno... (*sigh*)Arthur Avenue is all The Bronx has left.  I did some research, reviews looked great, photos of the food looked divine, and I took the bait.(*sigh*)Atmosphere was beautiful. Wait staff was amazingly attentive. Bathrooms were clean as a whistle (my boyfriend can attest to that.)  The food?  (*sigh*)I read and saw so many pictures of the Braised Short Ribs.  The waiter offered it on the nightly specials list and I took the bait.  (*sigh*)Now, I make braised short ribs at home.  I know what goes in to them (as far as love and labor) and how they should turn out.  The texture was spot-on.  They were slow-braised over quite some time. (CHECK!)  The flavor, though...  They tasted like they were braised (or maybe just "dressed"?) in a cheap, off-the-shelf jarred sauce.  There was absolutely no complexity in the flavor.  No real seasoning.  Just soft meat with cheap sweet pepper sauce spooned on top.  Umm... No.  (*sigh*)My boyfriend got the "Mixed Grill" plate.  It looked beautiful and I tried a piece of each meat.  Everything had that charred flavor, which was nice.  The prime complaint was that, he requested "Medium" in wellness.  Everything was "Well Done".  He would have sent it back, but we had a Yankee/Red Sox game to get to by 7:05 that night, so we didn't have time to wait.  (*sigh*)The Tiramisu was very light and airy, and the Hazelnut Gelato was very creamy.  Espresso was well brewed.  In general, it wasn't "Bad".  But we left the restaurant having the same conversation we have 90% of the time we leave restaurants; "Why do we bother going out?!?  We're too food-snobby!"   (*sigh*)
i had the rigatoni and it was a bit greasy but was still very good. For dessert i had the biscotti and gelato which was an amazing combination as well as the Nutella pizza being delicious

The service that you will get here is impeccable. Every single staff member is very well trained and very, very polite. You will feel like you are actually in Italy due to the ambiance, the music, but most importantly, the food. Favorites: arugula salad and prosciutto pizza. P.S. The limoncello is so strong!

Relaxed atmosphere and friendly service offering comforting Italian dishes prepared exceptionally well with fresh ingredients. The short rib appetizer is worthy of five stars on its own. Like any Italian restaurant worth its salt, they did not make us rushed us out, despite plenty of patrons waiting outside for a table. I will dream of my Sunday supper there until I get to return. Bravi!
Well worth the trip. Absolutely fantastic food. We had the pasta special, capriccioso, and pear and goat cheese salad. All fantastic

Amazing!!!!!! From the minute you walk into this restaurant!!!! It feels like your strolling along a street in an Italian village. The decor is visually pleasing.  The food is so delicious. My husband gets a dish that is in a crockpot. Filled with different meats & a red sauce. Not sure of the name. The waitstaff is wonderful at helping you to pair wine with whatever your meal will be. I absolutely enjoy eating here !

The BEST restaurant on Arthur Ave. Everything here is good, you can't go wrong between the pizza and the pasta and the dessert. I have been everywhere on Arthur and this place is consistently the best. Also- I'm a vegetarian and my biggest problem is deciding what I want to eat.

Walked in on a Sunday afternoon and had to wait a while for a table.  I liked the atmosphere, a bit like an Italian courtyard, but not hokey. Service was excellent; our waiter knew how to attend to our needs without trying to be our new BFF. Food was very good... We had butternut squash pasta and beet risotto, both very good. My rigatoni was al dente, which I liked. The men all had meat with and were more than happy with osso bucco. Save room for dessert which isn't easy. Awesome cheesecake! If you don't mind waiting, it's worth it.
This place was great.  We were there for lunch on a Thursday.  Great food, service & atmosphere.  You sort of feel like your sitting on a street in Italy.  Just awesome.

The pizza at this place is incredible!  Fresh mozzarella and tasty sausage on top of a delicious crust. Mangia!  We stopped in for lunch, a group of friends, started with the pizza and a bottle of chianti. Then moved onto the pasta course - the risotto was very nice, and the rigatoni was fantastic!  Attentive table service, what's not to like?!

After hearing about how good the pizza was here, my husband and I knew we had to come. We have been wanting to check out Arthur Avenue and the Bronx's Little Italy for a while, so we decided to include this while we were exploring. We arrived 15 minutes before it opened on a Sunday and there were already people waiting to get in. By the time the place opened, there was a line down the block to get in. Keep this in mind when coming! They brought everyone in and took everyone's names and after an out 5 minutes, started seating everyone. My husband and I had looked at the menu outside, so we already knew what we wanted to order. As soon as the server came we ordered: capricciosa and the caprese. Our food came out REALLY fast! The pizza's were incredible. The flavors were unbelievable. The sauce was perfect, the dough of the pizza was perfectly flavored and a little chewy, a little crispy, totally delicious. The ingredients used were fresh and tasty. As we were eating, we scoped out the other table's food and everything looked absolutely amazing. The pastas looked incredible, the other pizzas looked phenomenal, the appetizers looked to die for. There is not a single questions that we will be back to try everything else. This place is old school Italian that has been slightly modernized. I felt like I was back in Rome from when I studied abroad with the delicious home style Italian food that was served at this place. Come back! Come early! Be prepared to wait! And bring your appetite!

After a fun afternoon exploring the New York Botanical Garden, my party of two decided that we wanted to grab some local grub.After doing some Yelping, we decided on this place since we were in the mood for 'authentic NYC' Italian food.Boy, we totally nailed it with our choice! After being seated promptly, we were quickly greeted with ice cold glasses of good tasting water and a decent assortment of fresh bread and virgin olive oil.Not soon thereafter, our waiter came over to greet us and gave us the lowdown on the specials for the night. I decided to go with one of them and my partner decided to try a chicken parm-like dish. We placed alcoholic drink orders as well, which also came nice cold and quickly!Our clams appetizer was incredible in regards to flavor and plentiful! Our respective entrees were very delicious as well. We were both incredibly satisfied with the quality and quantity of food. We felt terrible leaving some on the plate, but we had to in order to make sure we could walk out of there!The service food and refreshingly lively and open ambiance was amazing. When in the Bronx, this will certainly be the top dining option we look for!

Everything was fantastic - food, service, and decor. We went for lunch to save ourselves a wait; people were lined up at noon. But, we got seated quickly and had a spacious table for six. I recommend getting a pizza and the calamari. We also had an amazing pasta special. I'm not sure you can go wrong with anything on the menu.

Love the high ceiling! Joyous waiting staff. Delicious foods. The big clock is cool. Don't let it door to fool you. The bar area is ordinary, the big mirror is kind of ... but after the tunnel, you'll be greeted by the high ceiling dining room. The Chianti is better than the pinot noir. We've:- Quattro formaggi - polenta with mozzarella- Brasato e peperoni - short rib with red bell pepper- Zuppa di Vongole - clams- Margherita Tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, parmigiano & basilThe bell pepper is too sweet for my taste but the dish is delicious. They have short rib for appetizer which I have, and main course. I'm glad for the choice because the next table ordered it as the main and it is huge.Dislike: their wine glasses, like 20+ years old and thick, almost ruined my wine ... Pls change them! The basil leaves are old too. I always keep a pot of basil and other herbs on the kitchen counter at home - so I know pretty leaves are easy to have. Belmont is the area and Arthur Ave, one way street is the main drag. Love the neighborhood. It feels a little old fashioned: they get their supplies from the neighbors. While waiting for our table, we discovered some unbelievable gems: Casa della Mozzarella, pasta shop, pork shop, bakery ..

Bronx's Elite Coal OvenEntering Zero Otto Nove (089) feels like walking into a cave. You start at a staging area-like bar where you wait for your guide, then through a narrow hallway you finally get to a region that opens up into an expansive stone room. There's a stillness of the marble all around you as the inhabitants intensely hover over their feed, with the oven fire in the center keeping everyone warm and safe.The Salerno-style pies are expectedly full of flavor, with the oven being wood and coal-fired. And the ingredient list satisfies the checkmarks of champions with San Marzano tomatoes, buffalo mozzarella and basil on the Margherita. Other pies dazzle like La Riccardo's with butternut squash puree, smoked mozzarella, pancetta, and basil pie (see pictures).The mix of heat sources do a great job, but now i fully realize the smarts of the rotating oven... here, the pizza guys keep having to rotate and it can lead to some human error ( aka artistry ) at times.Beware only ordering pies, it's may not be appreciated by the staff. Pizza is plebian, and they do not consider themselves plebes. They consider their kitchen to be a little more well rounded than that - and their purses at a higher level. Personally I don't give a pepperoncini, but to fit in, order your pizza as an appetizer to do like the proper Arthur Avenue kinsmen do. Some people say it's old school, some say it's new. I don't know and I don't care. It is full of expectations and they are unapologetic for it. The chefs work hard, with great ingredients, and turn out a great pie. They can hold themselves however they like.Opened: 2007Distinction: Coal and wood-fired oven. Elite pie of the Bronx. 089 refers to the area code of owner Roberto Paciullo's hometown, Salerno.Transit: B, D to Fordham Rd. (long walk from here)2nd Location: 15 West 21st St, Manhattan

Excellent food - atmosphere and service!  Butternut puree/mushroom pizza is incredible!  Salads, entrees - everything is wonderful!  Pancetta/Proscuito and Mozzarella appetizer was a hit also!Highly recommend and so pretty!

We recently dined here. The menu has changed; even the little car is gone. The veal and pasta dishes we enjoyed previously were not available. My friend ordered chicken scarperiello which had no sausage.  We ordered a chicken dish and pasta. My wife couldn't eat the chicken because it was tough. The pasta was overcooked. Disappointed!

Food was good as usual but the moment we walked in things were down hill .. The hostess and her friend were chatting in whatever language they speak after numerous customers walked in to ask how long a wait was .. Then they proceeded to send people to a "New" restaurant because they clearly didn't want them in the restaurant ... Hopefully the owner or manager sees this and let's the staff know , It's rude to speak in a foreign language around customer's who speak English

Love the dining room and decor. Kind of like a Piazza in an Italian city. Not a great bar area but I don't think they were aiming for a big bar scene. Nice Wine list as well. They serve pizzas in the style of the city of Salerno.(Crispier crust as compared to Naples style). They are phenomenal. Especially the pizza with butternut squash, scamorza ( smoked mozzarella) and pancetta! The Malfade pasta with chick peas, pancetta and pecorino cheese is deliciously simple. Other food options are hit or miss. The Nutella pizza for dessert, was like heaven, especially when paired with a glass of Moscato d'Asti. One of the only true Italian joints in The Bronx. This borough is full of Italian-American red sauce joints but they have their place too. This place is my go to for a great pizza pie or pasta with a decent bottle of Italian red.

Based on recommendations and prior visits by one of our party, four of us went for dinner tonight.  Overall, I was disappointed.  We shared a pizza Quattro Formagio for an appetizer and it was very tasty and good but a little salty.  Two of our main courses were disappointing.  Both the pasta al forno and the caniglio alla cacciatore (rabbit stew) were too salty.  I expected the rabbit to be very tender and come off the bones easily.  While the rabbit tasted fine (and the sauce was very good), it was very difficult to remove it from the bones, even after they brought me a steak knife.Atmosphere is very nice, like a real Italian trattoria.Service was excellent and they were very good about filling water glasses.Maybe we made poor choices with our entrees.  It's a nice restaurant, but the entrees were disappointing.

Ordered the meatball pasta, swordfish,and the squid ink pasta. You could tell the ingredients were fresh, but the meals were all a bit oversalted. Our server didn't have much of a personality, and offered zero help with suggestions, but the other servers compensated for that as well as remaining staff. Atmosphere is great.

You walk straight onto a street in Florence when you go to zero otto nove. It actually is more of a 3.5, that's not an option though. The pizza is pretty great brick oven and fresh ingredients. I had the Ragu very nice presentation. It was okay kinda left a funny taste in my mouth. I think I may have ordered poorly the pasta dishes running around look pretty great. Would try again for better results.

Following a recommendation, had a really good lunch today. The low down: 5 women: 1 bottle of Nero D'Avola, 1 Caprese pizza, 3 entrees: Mafalde e Ceci, Ragu Salernitano, Pollo Capriccioso, 1 side: Cavolfiori Stufati. The bill came to $120. Unreal! I would definitely come back for more of their brick oven pizzas (though still full, my mouth is watering thinking of that crust), and more of the Mafalde e Ceci. The pork skin braciola in the ragu was my least favorite-the texture threw me off. Ummmm no. The cauliflower side was a nice add to our meal. The chicken dish looked great but it was just ok to me. Others in the group liked it more. The menu is quite extensive and from looking down from the upstairs loft area, all the food on all the tables looked and smelled fantastic. The restaurant itself is decorated well and the service was excellent. Thank you!

Our third stop on Scott's Pizza Tour! The location to me is perfect NY - Arthur Ave!!! The area makes me feel like I've stepped back in time a little where mom and pop still run the show. You walk into the restaurant and are confronted with a staff who clearly speak Italian/other languages which to me - makes it legit. We were seated upstairs but got to pass by the main dining room. There is a great pizza oven that is kind of a work of art and definitely dining entertainment if you are in this part of the restaurant.  The staff seemed very attentive and from the looks of the food I passed by I'd go back here for sure. BTW: this meatball dish this guy had, had me near mauling him to try a bite. The pizza came out quickly and was the smallest most "artisanal" looking slices if you will. It was an average thin crust with the big chewy air bubbles of dough. There was just the right amount of char on the crust and bottom giving it that taste that you just can't replicate at home in a standard oven. The cheese was perfectly salty and abundant and there was just a few pieces of basil on top each slice. This pizza to me was the best one of the day, I may have even had a second slice!!!! Oh, they also have really great olive oil sitting on the table to dip your crust which it out of the world. I want to go back to Zero Otto Nove really badly but am afraid given the long train ride from Greenpoint, I may never do that. But - lesson learned if you live near, are adventurous, or generous on spare time GO!!!!!

Delicious food and the place is beautiful.. I have been there several times and sometimes Im lucky with the services sometimes not to much but in general the service is OK but the place and the food are very recommended

One of the best pollo scarpariello I've had !We had dinner at the bar since the waiting for the table was 20 minutes,however the service was good and quick by the bartender Andre!We definitely be back !!

We came on a Wednesday evening and were seated right away. The restaurant is definitely nice looking but it is not well lit. The service was good. I just wished the food tasted better. The pasta ribbons with broccoli rabe had too much of the cheese and the broccoli rabe lacked seasoning. The breaded chicken breast was dry and overcooked.

Came here last Friday evening for a date night dinner.. I have been here in the past and loved it, but this was not the same experience. Aside from the wait being 40+ minutes at around 8pm, the food we ordered was subpar and so was the service. We ordered the eggplant appetizer, there was barely anything to it and the goat cheese didn't taste fresh. The chicken dinner was more like chicken bruschetta and that's not what it was supposed to be. Our waiter basically pushed us out once he put the check down when we were just having a nice conversation trying to enjoy the remainder of our dinner date. I was disappointed since this place is always awesome, maybe just hit it on a bad night, at least I hope!
Great pasta, great pizza, great atmosphere. Not worth its own trek up to Arthur Ave, but a lovely spot to hit on a tour.

This place is adorable! The decor was so cute, the eggplant appetizer was unique and delicious, the sea bass with clams was perfectly cooked (though I sort of regret not getting the housemade pasta), and my dessert had 4 kinds of chocolate! Heaven.

The pizza is amazing, the staff is amazing. My grandparents would approve. I'm obsessed with how the restuaunt looks inside too. Make sure you keep in mind this place doesn't take reservations and doesn't seat you till the entire party is there. All and all a great experience.

This was one of my the most delicious meals of 2016.  I went there with one of my very closest friends.  We're from New Jersey, and she just trusted that Arthur Avenue would be the real Little Italy of New York.  Boy, we were impressed with this restaurant.  It looks like nothing from the street, but once you walk back into the main dining area, you feel like you're in Rome.  It's very European in every aspect.  I just need to get back.As a tip, it's not too far from the Bronx Zoo and from the New York Botanical Garden.  If you have kids, you might not want to go here afterwards, but if you're with adults, it's relatively easy to combine a trip to either place with a meal here.

We have been going here for many years and I am usually a fan.  The pizza is spectacular, the specials are usually good too.  But, I need to tell you that if you order the Chicken Scaripello, it is not really chicken scarp.  No potatoes, no sausage, no peppers or vinegar.  Now, I know that the recipe can be a little different, but it usually has some of the aforementioned ingredients.  At first I thought they forgot to finish off the plate, then someone at another table had the exact same plate.  I will not be ordering that again!  Stick to the pizzas, pasta and wine and you can't go wrong!

This place was lovely, accommodating, and efficient... and the food, superb!  That arugula salad with shaved parmesan was sooooo tasty that I'm still thinking about it. The special homemade radicchio pasta with a veal ragu was to die for.  The chicken cutlet with tomatoes was HUGE and wonderful, and the linguine puttanesca was traditionally fabulous.  The breads, savory and wonderful.  The atmosphere... felt like I was in the courtyard of a restaurant in Lucca.  The only downside is that they don't take reservations, they are ALWAYS busy, and there may be a wait.  The upside is that there's a wait because they're WORTH it.  Our new go-to!!

I wish I could write reviews for the pasta and other dishes, they all sound so outrageous.Arthur Ave is really a Pain in the A** to get to from my home. I live on Long Island and to get here I have to fight traffic on the L.I.E., cross a major bridge and finally get on the Cross Bronx expressway. The Bronx is where I go to see the Yankees or funerals. Don't bother me!But deep down, I wanna go to a real Little Italy. Where they have outrageous Italian delis, cheeses and bakeries. Yeah.. NYC has Little Italy but it annoys me when I always go downtown.The stars aligned today and I knew I had Trattoria Zero Otto Nove on my Bronx list. Trattoria Zero Otto Nove is open for lunch until 2:30 so I knew to get there early.Walking in, I'm greeted by this drop dead gorgeous Italian hostess. She's talking in Italian to a customer, I knew I was in the zone. We're able to snag a table before the rush crowd. Once we're seated, It's beautiful inside! It looks like an Italian villa. I'm here for lunch and I'm on a mission, to taste the best pizza on the planet. I hate to compare my all time favorite Luzzos to Trattoria Zero Otto Nove because I have not had their pastas, sauces and meat dishes. And I don't care who's the hostess, I want to sample pizza nirvana.First off, the mozzarella is fresh and creamy. I'm starting to swoon at this point. I ordered the Diavola, their spicy sopressata pizza cooked in a wood burning oven. Pizza perfection, its very good. One of my top five pizzas for sure.Just not the king of all pizza. Hey, 5 yelp stars for sure. I can't wait to come back when the stars align again. I highly recommend Trattoria Zero Otto Nove.

I'm going to echo Tracy's review from 11/28 --- SLOW IT DOWN.  Food was delicious, got bread and water promptly and regularly, and the homemade pasta was spectacular (Broccoli Rabe).  But SLOW IT DOWN.  Everything just came out SO fast...the waiters (all with heavy Italian accents) spoke so fast...and they were SO attentive...it was just a little much.  Slow it down, and just let me and my friends enjoy my meal without everything being thrown at me so quickly.  Treat me like I'm in Italy, enjoying my meal at a reasonable pace, and dont need everything super fast.  Dont worry so much about turning around the tables so much.  And this is, after that, easily a five-star place.

Greeting- yes but will not seat until all are presentVibe- Italian alleyway No AmexNo regular coffee expresso or capachinoBR- suck two unitsParking- street challengingPrice- expensiveService- sucksWine list- all Italian $39 least expensiveFoodFresh mootz is ok at bestCharcuterie board is ok $25Octopus was tastyChik scarpierello was very good $18Chik mattone was tough $22Rigatoni zucco tastelessDessertsCannoli was doa. RefrigeratedChoc cake excellentWIGB? No

Had a delicious lunch of Pollo Capriccioso....huge portion which I could only eat half of.  Fantastic bread basket which was refilled without our asking.  First time here and would definitely go back!

Amazing butternut squash truffle oil pizza. Good quality starter bread. Fresh ingredients. Great sauces in both the pasta, and fish. Salads are small portioned and tried their Pinot Noir wine, which could be better, but overall great experience. Spectacular interior decor job.

Food is very good, but this place is very pricey.  Many main courses do not come with a side dish such as a small bowl of pasta or vegetable, or a small salad.  Side dishes are $7 to $10 more.  It makes a reasonable entree very expensive.  Also, we had to ask for bread and water.  It was not automatically put on the table when we sat down.

Quite enjoyable lunch.  Only take walk ins so it too a few minutes to get seated, but this process was well organized and painless.  Ordered a pizza and pasta to share for lunch. Both were very good and portions fair for the price.  Only complaint is that they won't serve a half portion of pasta, for our three year old daughter, a 12 dollar portion of plain pasta seems slightly excessive. Will go back, but only for a night out with the adults.

I've been here with my family about 3-4 times now. the food is delicious. all homemade pasta, wonderfully seasoned, decent portions. Pizzas are great too. The staff has always been very friendly and attentive. I have not found a better atmosphere, it feels like you in a restaurant in  italy. I only took off 1 star because they are stingy with the greated parmesean, i asked for extra for our table, (4 of us) and he brings us a little plate with about 3 tbls on it. and our waiter spoke so fast, with a heavy accent, none of us at our table understood what he was saying. Im sure they get so tired of repeating it over and over but its slightly noisy so it would have been better if he just slowed down a bit.

If I had an Italian granny, I'd want her to have  a dining room like the one here, with high ceilings, a big oven, and sepia colored walls to give the feeling that you are eating somewhere in granny's villa in the verdant mountains of Italy. My Italian granny would be able to cook huge plates of pasta so delicious each bite would feel like a granny's hug, comforting and filled with care and love. Perhaps an Italian granny awaits me with some future reincarnation, but for now, I defer to Trattoria Zero Otto Nove to satisfy me in the just how Nonna  would cook it department.A tiny car marks the entrance and storefront. My friend, who grew up on Arthur Avenue and was giving me the grand tour, explained it was similar to the old cars that one used to drive in Italy. Inside, the restaurant itself is beautiful. Past the bar we went, into a large room with  a skylight in an intimately lit dining area There's a wood fired oven; for the pizzas, I surmised.  Even with the dim lighting, the scene before me reminded me instantly of Botticelli's Primavera. This wasn't outdoor dining, but It was charming, rustic, with warmth and conviviality in the friendly smiles of the waiters and in the relaxed joy so evident in the diners. The breadbasket had Italian bread and focaccia, so fresh and not even needing the olive oil provided as a dip. I had the Linguine Al Nero Di Seppia, squid ink pasta with cuttlefish. The waiter had asked if I wanted the pasta in a red sauce, perhaps worried that a dish colored all black would frighten me. I asked him how it was traditionally prepared and he said with just the squid ink, garlic and oil. When in Nonna's villa, do as Nonna would do. It was marvelous, with perfectly cooked pasta made spectacular by the seemingly simple sauce of squid ink, garlic and oil. Indeed, the folks here knew how to cook. My friend had the Costelette Di Maiale Organic. The two pork chops were so huge if you're ever chased by a large, hungry dog, this is the doggy bag you want to offer as sacrifice. You'll be down the block to safety by the time the pooch finishes eating it. And the taste? Well, my friend comes from a family that makes its own pasta sauce from scratch every year, with buckets of plum tomatoes, and has a brother who actually slices whole almonds by hand to put into his bean casserole. And my friend, who had eaten here before, was very pleased. We were so stuffed we opted out of dessert, preferring to walk a bit and then sample some of the bakeries in the area. Portions were huge, so we both happily had leftovers to cart away.If you are around Arthur Avenue, do stop by for some outstanding Italian food served by efficient, pleasant waiters. By itself, the food would be worth a visit. But the pretty ambience of the place makes it terrific for a meal with friends, a date, and even family. And if someone's having a birthday, ask the congenial waiters to do their  pretty good rendition of the birthday song.
Great food!Good service. There was a huge party at the same time we were having dinner so it was a little pain in the butt to get servers over to our table.I would def come back again !

After reading the Yelp reviews, I was looking forward to dining here when we visited the Bronx.  Either we were there on an 'off' night, or these reviews were posted by friends and family.  The pasta special ($29) was too soft and totally tasteless, the zuppa de clams flavorless, the bread cold and prices too high.  Their pizza might be good, but that's it!  Give me the ol' school tried and true restaurants (Dominic's or Mario's) on Arthur Ave. any time!  Honestly- every dish should have been sent back!Our bill was over $100 for a mediocre (and that's being kind) meal!

My friend is Italian from the Bronx and knows her Italian food! She recommended we come here and I'm glad we did. You feel like you stepped into a small town in Italy as you walk in. Love the decor and the car outside. When we got there on a Sunday afternoon around 1pm, there wasn't a huge line but it got super busy after us. The line by the hostess got a bit confusing and she crossed our name off without calling us. Eventually we got seated after 30/40 minutes which isn't too bad, but it was unorganized. As far as the food, delicious! I got a the broccoli rabe pasta (which was a bit bitter but still great! My favorite was the butternut squash pasta (Rigatoni a zucca)  that my friend got! The seafood Risotto (Risotto alla pescatore) was great as well.  Price is relatively cheap for the quality of food you're getting. I would definitely recommended

Came here for an informal lunch. Dining room is fairly small so had a short wait. Shared a margherita pizza , an appetizer size eggplant parm, and another appetizer of sausage, cannelloni beans and broccoli rabe. All was delicious.Also fantastic crusty bread and dipping oil. The only thing that got to me was no coffee!!!! I didn't want cappuccino and didn't want espresso. Just a plain old cup of coffee! Had to go down the block to a nearby bakery for coffee and Charlotte Russe!

I sat at the bar because the wait for a table was going to be at least 45 minutes on a Sunday night. I had a riccardo, which was quite interesting because they used butternut squash in place of tomato sauce. The bread was thin but not crispy, and the toppings worked well together, though perhaps it was a little on the salty side. I also had a limoncello prosecco cocktail, which was very smooth and flavorful. The bartender was quite friendly.
Great atmosphere, good food, had the striped bass with baby clams and tomatoes special. Would definitely recommend. Complete wine list or good selection of glasses.pasta is fresh

Came here for dinner.. amazing!Love the inside, it has a very Italy feel. The food was very good, reasonably priced, and just overall amazing flavor. The waiter gave us the specials of the  and made it sound so good, we ended up ordering 2 dishes from the specials menu, and it was delicious !I would definitely be back !!

Good Italian restaurant. A little overhyped. Average food, romantic setting, very nice ambiance and good service. Comfortable seating, clean. Portions are average. Prices a little high for quality and size of portions.

We ordered the lamb pasta special.   It was so delicious.   It was seasoned to perfection.  Salads were really fresh and the dressing was a nice surprise.  The atmosphere reminds me of the authentic restaurants in Italy.

Came here for a birthday dinner. Very excited as I thought this would be authentic Italian food which is hard to come by. Ordered the muscles as an appetizer they came to the table and right away had an odor of smelling bad. I had almost 5 closed muscles which were obviosuly bad... They should of never served this. After that I ordered the pasta al forno which had looked delicious from the pictures and ask I thought they made the pasta homemade. My mistake ! The pasta was undercooked and everything lacked flavor. My boyfriend had the osso buco special... The meat was ok but the risotto was gross no flavor and was over cooked even salt couldn't help it. Overall I was really disappointed in the food the service was pretty great very attentive and kept checking in. I might go back to try the pizza as that looked very good and they have a brick over right in the dining area.

This place is awesome!  We picked this place because it had such great YELP reviews and I get it.  We waited 20 to 30 minutes for a table on a Saturday night.  Dinner was well with the wait!  Iwe shared the hot appetizer and the Freddo appetizer.  We ordered the beef ribs and the risotto with hot Italian sausage and we had a margarita pie too.  Food was great   The service was exceptional and the atmosphere was great too!  We will definitely be back soon!
Some of the best Italian food I've had in years. And a really nice atmosphere. Service was also near perfect.

Excellent and fresh!The menu is extensive and offers a wide range of selections. However, mostly everything we had at my table was from the daily specials. Make sure to try a seafood dish - fresh fish or soft shelled crabs. Also make sure to try one of their amazing pasta dishes - they do some creative things with pasta, veggies, sauces, and cheese! The pizzas are also freshly made right in front of you in the dining room pizza oven. So many good choices and the staff is very helpful.Don't forget about the wine and cocktail selection!

There was no wait for 2 people at around 7:45 on a Friday night, so we were seated immediately. The ambiance of the restaurant is really cool, it goes far back and it feels like you are sitting outside on the streets of Rome at a trattoria. Our service was extremely fast, and it seemed as though our waiter was from somewhere in Italy, which made the experience that much more authentic. We got the meatballs with polenta and goat cheese, which were delicious, I wish that there was more meath though! We also split  a margherita pizza which was prepared and cooked extremely fast and was delicious. If you plan on splitting a pizza however, dont go hungry! Their personal pizza sized! We also got Prosecco and Pinot Noir to drink which were both perfect and reasonably priced. To top off the meal, we ended with tiramisu which was out of this world. I highly recommend that dessert. I definitely plan on going back again in the near future!

Great food on Arthur Ave. very authentic, homemade pasta , great pizza . Service was good . Best to eat in the small garden room in the back . Desserts where good . A very nice place . Classy and tasty . I would go back for sure. Very busy so you might have to wait , but worth it.

Three years ago I went to this restaurant and had an awful experience. Last week I went to have dinner with my husband and a couple of friends. The food was good. The service was again was not great one of the waiters would rush to fill our glass would spill water ever time. The restaurant is super cute and has a ton of tables.

This is a very busy restaurant, so expect to have a bit of wait.  We sat at the bar and enjoyed some cocktails!  And really, there wasn't anything bad about this place.  It was fine. Not amazing, not even really that good, just fine.  Pizza's were interesting, but really I think our dining experience would have been better with the pasta.  Service was a little interesting, as it seems we circled through about 4 different waiters!

This place is soooooo good. No reservations so there's usually a wait which can be a drawback for a hungry crowd so be aware. But the seating in the back is so cool! They have amazing eggplant parm, tiramisu, among pretty much everything else. Very popular spot for college students with visiting parents. Now that I graduated, I am going to miss this place

Walked 30minutes to get here. I must say it was so worth it. I had been looking for a place for my only cheat day in my mini vacay, this was totally worth it. From the moment you are seated you receive excellent service. We got there about 50 min till closing time so service was pretty much all to our selves . My waiter helped me out from showing him pictures on Yelp. Which was great. Our food was orgasmic . If I'm ever in town again I will be visiting this place again. Pictures do not do justice. The pizza omg was the best I've ever had.

The bread was bland, but the service was great, and the interior was spacious yet felt cozy.We ordered the Mafalde Porcini e Provola and the Pasta al Forno. Both were prepared al dente. The sauce and meats were delicious.
I enjoyed the food. I have a pizza and the meatballs as my appetizer. I knocked off one star because the service was inconsistent. Some waiters were more attentive than others.

We've tried the margherita & fra diavolo, halibut/clams, steak, as well as the butternut squash pizza and potato pizzas. We've tried several different specials because they always sound interesting, but usually end up liking the pizzas and standard pastas the most. It's a beautiful space and special experience every time. Although the area is not transit friendly, it's worth the visit and this is a must stop.

First time here and it was impressive. Friendly welcome from the hostess. Friendly welcome from our waiter. They have a great traditional menu and super-fresh specials. We had some of each including: Scallops and Shrimp with Pork bits on Radicchio; Risotto with Fava Beans and Beets; Skate fish with thin slices of potato, halved grape tomatoes and basil. The ambience was lively. There is a lot of a natural light and the wall murals make it feel almost like you're on a little side street in Italy. Highly recommend!

I ate here about a year and half ago and never forgot about it! I ordered shaved lamb with pasta. Lovely dish. I really was impressed with the blonde, Italian waiter because I wondered if the Italian neighborhood really was, in fact, Italian. I would return to this restaurant, for sure. Enjoyed the trip out to Arthur ave.

Been there several times,service was good and the staff on point and friendly.Took some friends from out of town and they enjoyed a excellent Italian meal.Food is prepared per order not seating around for hours.When you are in the Bronx come to Arthur Ave can't miss the place there is a Blue Fiat in the front of the restaurant.

Ask any local and you will learn that Manhattan's Little Italy has moved. Increasing rents and the ever encroaching Chinatown have pushed Little Italy to the Bronx and Arthur Avenue. You can't go wrong with any of the spots on Arthur Ave but I particularly like Zero Otto Nove. On a Sunday evening, get your name in early and expect to wait. It's family dinner night and everyone was waiting at this spot. Having gone a few times and with only two in the dinner party, the wait was never more than twenty minutes. Once seated, enjoy an appetizer, a glass of wine, real authentic Italian dining. The service is spot on, the atmosphere is friendly, and the food is the best Italian I've ever had outside of Italy. The only down side is the place is a little echoey, so it gets hard to hear at times. However, bring the family, dress up or dress down, and break bread together without breaking the bank. This place is definitely worth it.
Came here to celebrate my moms bday during the week around 6pm. Every dish everyone ordered was delicious. Definitely will be returning again.
This is our favorite place in the Bronx and where we take all visitors. Really delicious food and amazing staff.
The place is nice and the service was good. Went for lunch with family and none of us were impressed with the taste of the food except for the pizza.

Came here for lunch with some co-workers after reading all the great reviews.  To start off the décor was awesome.  I would imagine during peak time it can get crowded, but the look of the restaurant was great. Next, the food was really really really good.  We ordered the pizza to share and got the la Cirillo.   This thing was awesome.  When I come back I am just getting this.   The flavors and crust were perfect.  We also go the short ribs special (very good) , some pasta dish (meh) and the Ragu salernitano (phenomenal).  I would definitely come back here, just to try the different pizzas.  BTW only 4 stars because for lunch I feel it was a little pricey ($101 total bill) . But maybe I am being cheap.

I got a chance to go to Zero Otto Nove a few weeks ago when I was in NYC and I was blown away.  Living on the West coast I don't have very many opportunities to try traditional Italian food but this place easily surpassed my expectations!     To start we had their antipasto platter.  A pretty traditional mix of meats/ cheeses but the quality is what stood out.  For years now I've always thought I disliked provolone cheese, just seemed mild and boring, but apparently I've never had the real thing, the provolone here was INCREDIBLE!  Way more flavorful than I ever thought it good be.     My girlfriend and I decided to split a pizza and a order of the Squid Ink Pasta for our main course.  Both dishes were incredible!  The pizza crust had the perfect texture, slightly toasted but not burnt.  The Pasta was also delicious, I'd never had squid ink before so I wasn't sure what to expect but I can honestly say now that I'm a fan :) .  The only warning I would give is to be careful if you have a formal event later in the day, my lips and tongue were stained black (totally worth it).     The service was excellent and complimented the food nicely.  I think the thing that really pushed it over the top for me was the decor, it totally feels like your in an Italian vila!  All in all I'd give Zero Otto an A+ .  If I ever find myself in Little Italy (Bronx) I know where I'm going.

This is only a review for the service here, because as much as I would have loved to try the food the waitstaff didn't seem to have too much interest in making that happen. I was pleasantly surprised when we walked in and the hostesses were nice and accommodating since we had a child with us and wished my husband a Happy Father's Day as we were seated. After that the waiter was pretty quick to bring us plates and water and even a special plastic cup with a straw for my daughter. We were really looking forward to this meal. Then he came back and read us the specials. All good up until now and nothing out of the ordinary. So we waited for him to come back to take our order. Just the three of us, so it didn't take long for us to decide....and we waited...and waited some more. After at least 20 minutes a table of 12 was sat next to us. We were starting to wonder where our waiter had gone, and after we had been seated for I'm guessing close to 30 minutes, he appeared and took the orders of the table of 12 that had just been seated without a glance at us. He was right next to us and just ignored us. He spent about 5 minutes with each person at that table taking their order and we thought, okay, this is insane that we've been sitting here this long and he's not even looking over here, but had a glimmer of hope he'd take our orders after he finished with them. Nope, he disappeared. After that our starving daughter was getting obviously cranky after having to sit and wait for food for so long (and so were we to be honest). We found another waiter and told him we had to leave because we'd been waiting so long and still hadn't even placed our order and our daughter just couldn't wait any longer. Everyone seemed really confused and another waiter asked in a panic if we'd placed our order and we said no, that was the problem no one took our order and he just threw his hands up in the air, like, "oh that's fine then" since they didn't have to worry about canceling an order. No apology...not a great feeling to leave a restaurant with. Even if we didn't have a kid, I think we still would have left after being so blatantly ignored like that. I think we stuck it out longer for her sake because she was super excited for pasta.

Holy hell this place was incredible. Found it on Yelp and came by for food after a long day with a date at the Bronx Zoo - and what a perfect ending it was. The interior was clean and beautiful, without being too fancy. The front features a bar with TV (soccer was playing)  and the hall to the back opens to a cavernous dining room with natural window lighting in the ceiling and a second floor balcony for dining too. For the quality and creativity of the food, this prices were totally reasonable. Bread and olive oil comes free to the table, and of course you have to drink a Peroni. The Riccardo pizza with butternut squash purée was fan-f*****g-tastic. The entire staff was gracious and our waiter was helpful in making suggestions- the menu gives a lot of option! What blew my mind is that my date and I walked in right when it opened at 4:30pm, and within 10 minutes, half the place was full. On a random Thursday afternoon. Wut. Living in Harlem will make it hard to go regularly, but I'll certainly be back and would highly recommend it.

The pizza was delicious....one of the closest we have had to the antica pizzerias in Naples.  They had a truffle asparagus and mushroom risotto special which was heavenly.  The hanger steak entree was decent - make sure to eat it with the rocket and mix it up.  Interior of the restaurant is beautiful as well.  A true gem and definately believe the hype of all of the yelp reviews!

The inside of the restaurant was very cute - almost as if you're sitting at some trattoria in Italy.  The food, however, was just OK.  The pizza was decent but salty and the beet salad was uninspiring and the burrata did not taste completely fresh - the fresh mozzarella was mushy and the cream tasted a bit off.  Thankfully, we didn't get sick. I'm disappointed that the place didn't live up to its hype.

I love this restaurant! It has a nice old Italian corner restaurant vibe when we were there on a Sunday noon. The food is very good and price is quite reasonable. We ordered more than we can possibly consumed. Their Pumpkin Pizza was delicious and plenty to be shared as an appetizer. We each ordered a pasta entree and was having a hard time finishing it. My dish was Pasta Al Forno and it was so filling with eggs, red sauce and pancetta! My husband ordered the spaghetti with ink sauce and I thought that was fabulous too. My father-in-law tried their Veal and it was amazing with their savory sauce. I would definitely come back again but probably order less!

Came to Arthur Ave for dinner on a Sunday. The hostess said it's a 30 min wait. Not a problem, we walked up the block and shopped at Rite Aid. Came back within 30 mins and got seated. The decor looks like you are sitting outdoor with high ceilings. The service was friendly and attentive. It's a busy restaurant. The server listed the daily specials and everything sounded great. We ordered the grilled calamari, squid ink pasta (mild - I should have gotten spicy), and braised pork shank all to share. Everything were delicious including the fresh bread. We were too full for dessert. Prices were reasonable given the portion you get. Didn't try the pizza. Will definitely return in the future.
I've eaten here three times, and each time it was fantastic. I'll definitely be going back.
Great italian food and service was on point.
Delicious food and excellent service.  Beautiful decor.  Doesn't look like much from the outside but it is beautiful inside.  Good value for quality of food you are getting.

Great food, reasonably priced.  Very attentive pleasant staff.  Three of us a great dinner, wine, appetizer & mains.  Pizza also fabulous with perfect crust and some novel and creative toppings.  Great place!

Went there on a Sunday evening with my boyfriend and we were blown away. Not our first time on Arthur Ave, but our first time at this restaurant. Wow is all I can say. We ordered the special which was grilled calamari & arugula salad, it was charred to perfection. Next we ordered the caprese pizza which was delicious, very cheesy, and had a well done crust so you could actually hold your slice without the cheese sliding off. I'm not a huge fan of personal pizzas since most times I end up having to eat them with a fork and knife because the crust is made too thin, but this was not the case. Last and definitely not least, we ordered the squid ink pasta, one of our favorites. It was unbelievable - cooked in a garlic & oil sauce it had so much flavor and you can tell the pasta was super fresh. I'm not a dessert person at all (probably haven't ordered dessert at a restaurant in like 2 years) and my dinner was so good I had to order something here. We got a chocolate mouse cake with a side of vanilla gelato to finish up the awesomeness that was this dinner. We are both Italian and I come from a family of great cooks and hold pretty high Italian food standards - I HIGHLY RECOMMEND !!
Went here for a lecture. Service was great, ambiance is good for Arthur Ave. Noise level was a bit high for the occasion. Portions were huge. Food was ok. Really liked the chocolate pizza!

Ambiance/decor is beautiful & staff is super friendly. Food was delicious but a tad pricey for the portions we received. Needless to say, we gobbled it all up & sipped 2 bottles of white wine... & so a brilliant night was had by all!

Seems like a lot of people have birthday dinners here - no less than 5 birthdays during our dinner. At 6pm on a Saturday, we had to wait 50 min for a table. As other reviewers have noted, cool decor. The service was okay - we had to ask for things like bread and freshly ground pepper, but the servers were polite and delivered what we asked for reasonably quickly. The food was just okay though. The appetizer and pizza we got were really salty, which kind of ruins things for me.  Maybe an off day?Pizza: We got the Diavola, which has red sauce, fresh mozzarella, and spicy sopressata. I don't blame the sopressata for being salty. However, the pizza dough was also salty and the tomato sauce was SUPER salty. The pizza would otherwise have been great. The crust was both crisp and chewy, the tomato sauce was thick and flavorful, and the mozzarella was great. The salt did me in though. Antipasti: We got the Polpettine, Polenta & Caprino. Again, this would have been great if it hadn't been so salty. The polenta had a nice smoky flavor which I liked and the meatballs were pretty tasty, if not very warm. However, the polenta was a tad too salty on its own so it was a little hard to take when combined with the salty tomato sauce.  I ended up having a lot of bread and water.Pasta: We got the pasta special of the day, which was a thick linguine with grilled veggies. The linguine was like super dense udon and had a very slightly pasty, sticky texture to it. Still, this was the most enjoyable dish of the meal, perhaps because we specifically asked that they cut back on the salt. For dessert we had the dish with strawberries and cream (I'm blanking on the name). This would have been good, but the strawberry sauce drizzled over it had an artificial flavor. Also, the dish was supposed to be made with fresh cream, but something about the taste and texture reminded me suspiciously of cool whip. Maybe it was just the artificial taste from the strawberry drizzle bleeding into the cream.We left full and I might go back if I was in the area. I don't think I'd seek it out though.

This was a great stop while strolling along Arthur Avenue.  We got there right when dinner was starting and had an antipasta plate, the arugula salad, and a pizza.  It was enough food for the table, the service was great, and the quality was excellent.  I would love to come back and try the pasta and entrees.

our group decided to visit Arthur Ave and try this contemporary Italian joint. this was worth the 1 hr trip! granted this place doesn't take reservations and we had to wait 45 minutes, but it's not that bad since there are lots of places you can check out in the two block radius as you are waiting. the hostesses at the front got us our table within the quoted time and provided us with updates as we waited. according to their web site, they aim to make food that overwhelms the senses.  to start, they provided us with baskets of bread. the bread was delicious. especially enjoyed the sun dried tomato cibatta. served with olive oil.  we ordered two pizza's: patate salsiccia and the la Riccardo. the pizza's were perfectly wood fired. delightful and very light, as in airy and refined compared to normal pizzas with toppings. definitely some of the best that I have had. the la Riccardo (butternut squash, smoked mozz, pancetta, and basil)  was surprisingly tasty. we shared a bunch of entrees: braised short ribs, a baked striped bass, osso bucco, risotto pescatore, and rigatoni special with lamb. all were tasty, but I especially enjoyed the short ribs, osso bucco, and risotto. the rigatoni was a bit too chewy for me but I was amused by the size of it. simply huge, like a hollow whistle  I liked the rustic nature of the food. the dining area is also pretty cool with the skylit atrium and brick structures. it's as though you are dining outside on a nice day in a small town in Italy. service was on point and the waiter was even amusing at times. enthusiastically recommended and would love to come back another time to try more items.

I have been coming to Arthur Avenue for over 30 years,and have eaten in every restaurant in Little Italy of Belmont.Zero otto nove is probably the best.My father and I have eaten here about 10 times and never had a bad meal.The waiters are very professional.and the restaurant itself reminds you of a rustic Italian kitchen.My father usually orders linguine puttanesca.with olives capers .My favorite is the ragu salernitano,which is sausage ,meatball,beef braciole,and cotennne,which is pigskin braciole.It is served in a sunday gravy.Everything is always made with the best ingredients.The bread basket is fantastic.Place is always packed,for a good reason.Great Italian restaurant on Arthur Avenue.
